item.title: Real Life Evaluation of Ferring's Zomacton® With the Zomajet® Vision X Device
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ferring is to collect long-term data on the treatment adherence and patient's acceptability when Zomacton®10 mg is administered with the Zomajet® Vision X device in patients with a growth hormone deficiency or Turner's syndrome. PE will measure rate of overall treatment adherence. the investigation location site is localized at the Hôpital des Enfants, CHU de Toulouse (France).
Trial Details
n=90
Start date: May 2014 - Completion date: Sept 2017 / October 2017
Source: NCT02018172

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: First Magnetic Device for Migraine with Aura Approved in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: eNeura Therapeutics secured the first FDA approval for its magnetic migraine treatment, the Cerena Transcranial Magnetic Stimulator (TMS). The device is aimed at relieving pain in patients >18 years of age that suffer from migraine headaches accompanied by an aura.
Device Description
http://www.eneura.com/tms.html
The portable handheld device is designed so that patients hold it with both hands against the back of their head and a button is pressed to administer magnetic pulses. The device utilizes a single-pulse Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation technology that delivers a non-invasive pulse of magnetic energy for less than one minute. In turn, this stimulates the occipital cortex in the brain, disrupts cortical spreading depression, the abnormal electrical activity underlying the aura phase of the migraine, and alleviates pain.
Trial Details - NCT00449540 http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00449540?term=NCT00449540&rank=1

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sagent Pharm. Launches Octreotide Acetate Injection in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The product is available in 5 vial presentations (3 in signle-dose vials and 2 in multi-dose vials). The 'product use' section of the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) features 2 indications: carcinoid tumours and VIPoma.
Presentations
  • For single-dose vials, each mL contains 50 mcg, 100 mcg or 500 mcg octreotide (as acetate) and the following inactive ingredients: 7 mg sodium chloride, 2 mg glacial acetic acid USP, 2 mg sodium acetate trihydrate USP and water for injection USP, q.s. to 1 mL.
  • For multi-dose vials, each mL contains 200 mcg or 1000 mcg octreotide (as acetate) and the following ingredients: 7 mg sodium chloride, 2 mg glacial acetic acid USP, 2 mg sodium acetate trihydrate USP, 5 mg phenol USP and water for injection USP, q.s.
Please see full information at : http://www.sagentpharma.com/octreotide-acetate-injection.html
About Sagent Pharmaceuticals
Sagent is an injectable pharmaceutical company, which develops and sources products, which it sells in the US.
Presence in China: 300,000 square foot FDA- and cGMP-compliant, sterile manufacturing facility located in Chengdu, China, that utilizes state-of-the-art isolation technology for aseptic filling. The facility is fully operational, was inspected by the FDA in 2012.
The Company offers a range of products across anti-infective, oncolytic and critical care indications in a range of presentations, including single- and multi-dose vials, pre-filled ready-to-use syringes, medical devices and premix bags, and it focuses to develop injectable products.
As of December 31, 2010, it marketed 22 products, all of which were generic injectable products, and had a pipeline, which included 46 new products represented by 77 Abbreviated New Drug Applications (ANDAs), which either are under review by the US FDA or were approved and their associated products are pending commercial launch.
Source: Sagent Pharm

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Positive Results from the Interim Analysis of Antisense's ATL1103 for Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The interim analysis from the POC trial was undertaken on the 8 patients who have completed the full 3 months of dosing at both dosing levels employed in the study. Enrolment into the 24 patient trial is expected to be completed early in the new year. The company looks forward to the reporting of the statistical analysis of the sIGF-I data from all patients (expected in the second quarter of 2014) and to the potential verification of results achieved in this interim analysis. Based on these interim results, the company will be following up interest from pharmaceutical companies in partnering the development of ATL1103 for Ph3 trials. Findings are provided below.
Findings
In the 4 patients who received the 400 mg per week dose, ATL1103 reduced sIGF-I levels consistently and by an average (mean) of 30% (range 4% to 48%) at week 14 (one week past the last dose) which is the primary efficacy time point for the trial. sIGF-I levels were reduced by a mean of 38% (28 – 48%) in the 3 patients who had lower body weights (58 - 83 kg at screening) and thereby received a relatively higher dose per kg bodyweight. The one patient showing the lowest sIGF-1 reduction at week 14 had the highest body weight (132 kg at screening).

At the 200 mg per week dose, no consistent reduction in mean sIGF-I levels was observed at week 14, although some sIGF-I reduction was noted in individual patients.

The time course data at the 400 mg per week dose generally shows a progressive rate of reduction in sIGF-I over the dosing period. This is further support for the therapeutic action of ATL1103 observed in this trial and suggests that continued dosing of ATL1103 at the 400 mg per week dose for longer than 3 months could result in additional reductions in sIGF-I.

While sIGF-I levels were substantially suppressed in 3 patients receiving the 400 mg per week dose of ATL1103, their sIGF-I levels did not reduce all the way to normal levels, however this is not surprising considering the study design was not optimised for this endpoint, the small number of patients analysed thus far and that their starting sIGF-I levels (2.4 to 5 times above normal) appear higher when compared to average starting levels of acromegaly patients in larger published clinical studies (e.g. 1.8 times above normal).

To date no patients dosed with ATL1103 have withdrawn from the study nor have any serious adverse events, believed to be treatment-related, been reported. So far, both doses appear to be well tolerated. The positive safety profile to date suggests the drug may be tolerated at higher levels than 400 mg per week and so the Company is considering the prospect of conducting a small add-on study to support the use of a higher dose in Phase III trials for dose escalation in patients with more active disease.

Other important parameters of drug activity being measured in all patients that will also be assessed at the end of the study include Growth Hormone and Growth Hormone Binding Protein levels along with a more comprehensive assessment of the safety data. Such additional data is expected to give further valuable insight into the safety, activity and mechanism of action of ATL1103 at both dose levels in this patient population.

Ph2 Design
- Design: randomised, open-label, parallel group study
- Objective: safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics and efficacy of two subcutaneous dosing regimens of ATL1103 in 24 adult patients with acromegaly dosed with ATL1103 for 13 weeks (3 months) with two months of follow up.
- Protocol: Two ATL1103 dosing regimens are being tested (a) 200 mg 3 times in the first week then once weekly thereafter (200 mg/week) or (b) 200 mg 3 times in the first week then twice weekly thereafter (400 mg/week).
Endpoints
  • The primary endpoints are (i) to evaluate the safety and tolerability of ATL1103 in patients with acromegaly, and (ii) to evaluate the single dose and multiple dose pharmacokinetic profiles of ATL1103 via the subcutaneous route in patients with acromegaly.
  • A secondary endpoint is the evaluation of ATL1103's effect on serum insulin like growth factor I (IGF-I) levels in patients. The secondary endpoint is the average percentage reduction in serum IGF-I levels at the end of treatment compared to baseline levels for each of the two dosing regimens used in the Ph2 study.
Drug Patent
ATL1103 commercialisation is covered by patents to at least 2024, with the potential for extensions up to 2029 in some countries and 2030 in the US.
Source: Antisente Therapeutics

item.title: Three New Patents for Restasis (Allergan's #2 Drug)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has obtained new patents for its eye drops. Earlier composition patent on the product is due to expire in May 2014. In June 2013, the FDA published guidelines indicating that a generic competitor could be approved without human testing, meaning the agency is conceptually open to the idea of granting approval to a generic without running a study.
The FDA said in its proposed guidance that conducting a study in humans to test whether the drugs are essentially equivalent would not be feasible or reliable due to the "modest efficacy" of Restasis.
Allergan estimates that 2013 sales of Restasis will come in at $900M to $920M (roughly 15% of total sales).
Source: FirstWord; Reuters

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Clinical Trial Data Capture Moves To A New Level With The Use Of Formula-1 Technology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment In September 2011 GSK announced a partnership with the Formula-1 McLaren Group to share knowledge and expertise with the aim of improving business performance. This weekend the fruits of their efforts were aired on British Television with Sky News highlighting how use of McLaren's monitoring technology is to be deployed in research trials in stroke and arthritis to monitor patient's reactions to new medications.
Smart sensors used by McLaren to track the performance of their cars on the track are being used in this context for the first time GSK hopes that by precisely tracking the movements of patients they will get earlier feedback on whether a drug helps to get them back on their feet.
Currently doctors try to estimate a patient's response to a drug by asking them to diarize how far and how often they walk.
Dr Caroline Hargrove, technical director at McLaren Applied Technologies, is adapting the sensors and the software used to analyse the data for human use.
"Rather than how fast you have gone round a lap, it's how many minutes of walking you have done," she said.
But sensors that are taped to the neck can monitor patients day and night, providing a far more objective - and accurate - measure of activity.
Dr Ravi Rao, a consultant rheumatologist and medicines development leader at the company, said the data can be analysed to determine the duration of an arthritis patient's stiffness in the morning.
"These quality of life measures, in terms of how a patient is functioning with a disease, are incredibly important - more important sometimes than a blood test or a physical examination."
GSK hopes the technology will speed up drug development.
http://news.sky.com/story/1185621/formula-one-technology-used-in-drug-trials

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EU Upholds Fampridine (FAMPYRA®) Patent
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The EU patent (EP-1 732 548 B) is set to expire in 2025, absent any additional exclusivity granted based on regulatory review timelines. In addition, FAMPYRA® received 10-year market exclusivity upon approval by the EU Commission that is set to expire in 2021. FAMPYRA® is indicated in the EU for the improvement of walking in adult patients with MS with walking disability (EDSS 4-7).
FAMPYRA® is exclusively developed and commercialized outside the US by Biogen Idec under a collaboration and licensing agreement with Acorda. (See Neurology4398: Biogen Idec Gains Rights to Acorda's Fampridine-SR).
AMPYRA® is covered by multiple patents providing coverage through 2027.
AMPYRA® has Orphan drug status providing market exclusivity through January 22, 2017.
Source: Acorda

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lilly and PeptiDream Sign Therapeutic Peptides Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PeptiDream will identify macrocyclic peptides as potential drug candidates, and Lilly will be responsible for any development.
Not disclosed.
PeptiDream's proprietary PD Platform is a highly versatile peptide generation and selection platform based on three core technologies; 1) Flexizyme, 2) translation, cyclization, and peptide modifying technologies, and 3) PD display.
The combination of these 3 technologies into the PD Platform allows PeptiDream to produce libraries of trillions of unique cyclic and helical nonstandard peptides with unparalleled diversity.
The PD Platform allows PeptiDream to identify hundreds of novel nonstandard macrocylic peptides against a target in weeks, covering a wide variety of peptide classes and structures.
Researchers can then screen hundreds of hits a week for the desired target binding, selectivity, and biochemical activity by independently expressing each peptide using PeptiDream's PDTS translation system, without the bottleneck of expensive and time consuming chemical synthesis. Leads can then be chemically synthesized and purified for further development.
Source: PeptiDream

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Pfizer and Pekin U. Ink GP Training and Development Project
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: General practice plays a vital role in China's medical system. Per the agreement, Pekin University Health Science Center will host activities subsidized by Pfizer. Details are provided below.
Peking University Executive Headmaster Ke Yang indicated that the center fully recognizes the importance of nurturing health professionals. It will therefore explore innovative training objectives, teaching concepts, curriculum settings, evaluation standards and faculty improvement.
The training and development project aimed at improving capabilities and quality at 20,000 community medical institutions in China.
Pfizer will also partially fund scholarship for 210 GPs to attend the University of Birmingham over the next 3 years.
Source: GBI Pharma

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: CHMP Postpones Final Decision On Teva/Active Biotech's Laquinimod
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Active Biotech noted on Friday that the CHMP has yet to reach a final decision on approval of Laquinimod for the treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis with a verdict is now anticipated in January 2014.
No explanation has been given for the delay with the overall review process having been initiated in July 2012.
Prospects for Laquinimod are viewed by analysts as uncertain as the European submission was based on results from two phIII trial ALLEGRO and BRAVO and BRAVO did not meet its primary endpoint of reduction in annualised relpase rates versus placebo.
Moreover, the US FDA has requested that a third phIII trial be undertaken under a special protocol assessment.
Teva still hopes that it will be able to launch the drug in 2014 having demonstrated that a significant difference was observed in annualised relapse rates in the BRAVO study when an inbalance between study arms was corrected.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Teva Has Stopped the Promotion of Zoladex in Germany
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Stefan Pfeifer (Business Unit Director Urology), we have learnt that Teva has stopped promotion of Zoladex, and that invitations to EAU and AUA have been cancelled. The agreement between the two companies is set to end on March 31, 2014. The question now is whether AZ will look at another partner or not. Another scenario recently emerged which indicates that Teva may be interested in acquiring Acino's goserelin.
The news comes from multiple sources that have independent direct contacts with TEVA reps. There have been rumours about difficult discussions between Astra and TEVA for some time, so this news was not a big surprise at all.

item.title: Data From PREVAIL to be Presented at International Congress
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medivation and Astellas have announced that additional data from the Phase 3 PREVAIL trial evaluating enzalutamide in patients with chemotherapy-naïve metastatic prostate cancer will be highlighted in a late-breaking oral presentation at the upcoming ASCO GU Cancers Symposium in San Francisco. Of note, B. Tombal will present the Ph2 results of enzalutamide monotherapy in hormone-naïve PCa patients.
- Enzalutamide in men with chemotherapy-naïve metastatic prostate cancer (mCRPC): Results of Phase 3 PREVAIL Study - Presenter: Tomasz M. Beer, OHSU Knight Cancer Institute, Oregon Health & Science University

• Session Detail: Welcome and General Session 1: Integrating Androgen Axis Therapy across the Disease Spectrum
(January 30, 2014 from 7:45 a.m - 9:45 a.m).

- Abstracts to be presented during General Poster Sessions

• (Abstract #62) Enzalutamide monotherapy: Phase 2 study results in hormone-naïve prostate cancer patients. Presenter: Bertrand Tombal, Université Catholique de Louvain, Cliniques Universitaires Saint-Luc (11:30 a.m. - 1:00 p.m., Thursday, January 30, 2014).
• (Abstract #247) Enzalutamide in men with prostate cancer resistant to docetaxel and abiraterone. Presenter: Mark Creamer Scholz, Prostate Oncology Specialists (12:00 - 1:30 p.m., Friday, January 31, 2014).

Source: GlobalData

item.title: Collaborations Pave The Way Forward For Merck's Development Of Its PD-1 Immunotherapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merck & Co has enterered into a collaborative agreement with GSK to study its experimental PD-1 immunotherapy MK-3457 in combination with GSK's approved oral kinase inhibitor Votrient (pazopanib) in advanced renal cancer.
Nature Of The Collaboration
Full details of the collaboration have not been disclosed but in brief the companies will conduct a phI/II trial to assess the efficacy and safety of MK-3475 in combination with Votrient in treatment-naive patients with advanced disease. The companies will also undertake studies of MK-3457 in combination with other products in GSK's portfolio in future.
Striking Results In Melanoma
Last month, Merck announced that MK-3475 significantly prolonged survival in a phI study in patients with advanced melanoma with the 12-month survival rate tracking around 81%, a figure that compares favourable with BMS's competing nivolumab (62%) and the (82%) seen for nivolumab in combination with BMS's Yervoy.
Other Areas Of Investigation
MK-3457 is being studied in 10 clinical trials for several malignancies including bladder, colorectal, gastic and renal cancer.

item.title: Galderma Looses Key US Patent Case
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : On Wednesday Galderma's monopoly on its brand-name acne treatment Differin Gel 0.3% in the US expired, when the generic drug company Tolmar Inc. and its lawyers at McDermott Will persuaded the Federal Circuit to invalidate Galderma's patents.
Significance Of This Patent Expiry

US sales of the product, which is the number 2 product worldwide in the topical anti-acne market were $125m in 2012 according to IMS.
Acne product sales represent the group's top selling therapy area in the year to December 2012, accounting for sales of Euro 356m versus group sales of Euro 1.59bn. Its overall sales profile is shown below.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: After raising its offer price from 336 crowns to 362 crowns, Algeta's board unanimously backed Bayer's sweetened offer. With the deal now secured, Bayer effectively gains full control of the prostate cancer drug Radium -223 (Xofigo).
Bayer's offer represents a 37% premium to Algeta's closing price on November 25th the day before the offer became public.
Background - see Oncology9340: Bayer in Early Stage Talks to Acquire Algeta.

item.title: Takeda Reinforces its Commercial Platform in Growth Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has established its wholly-owned subsidiary in Israel, the sixthiest entity after Algeria, Ecuador, Peru, Singapore, and Vietnam. According to Business Monitor International, pharma sales in Israel totaled $1.5bln in 2012 and are expected to grow at a CAR of 6% (between 2013 and 2017.
  • Population growth
  • Increase need for specialty treatments
HQ: Tel Aviv Area
Country manager: Arie Kramer (joined from AbbVie where he headed Finance and Strategic Commercial Planning. Previously he has served as GM, CFO at Novartis Consumer Health in Israel).
Mission: sales and marketing of selected products, with an initial focus on oncology
Business Development: local partners with complementary portfolios are sought
Major Products Sold in Israel: Actos, Atacand, Contoloc, Lucrin, Xefo, Mepact.

item.title: re: Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS 
Comment: The Belgium based, private company presented at ENDO2013 preclinical PK and efficacy data of its oral small-molecule NK3 receptor antagonist program. ESN364, the lead candidate issued from this program, is scheduled for FIM in 4Q:13 (endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome). Of note, the company is actively seeking partner for ESN282 (inflammatory diseases such as ulcerative colitis).  ...
Euroscreen has announced initiation of the Phase I clinical trial for ESN364. The main study objective is the assessment of the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of ESN364 in healthy male and female volunteers.
In addition, hormone levels will also be monitored as biomarkers of on-target activity.
Recruitment: Approximately 64 healthy subjects will participate in the study.
Timelines and Next Steps: Successful completion of this European Phase I clinical trial will enable the initiation of Proof-Of-Concept Phase II studies of ESN364 in patients suffering from sex-hormone related disorders such as Endometriosis, Poly-Cystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS), Uterine Fibroids, and possibly other related diseases. Phase II studies are projected to start in Q4, 2014.

item.title: PMS Study of BOTOX® for NDO in Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Poised to start soon and last 3 years, this trial will evaluate the safety and efficacy of BOTOX® to treat urinary incontinence in patients with neurogenic detrusor overactivity (NDO) not adequately controlled by anticholinergic drugs. PE will measure the number of participants with AEs and ADRs.
Timelines
Completion date: Dec 2016
Recruitment
Approx 600 participants (both genders) with urinary incontinence due to NDO treated with BOTOX® as per local standard of care in clinical practice.
Source: NCT02010788

item.title: Allergan Reprimanded By The ABPI For Continual Breach Of The Code Of Practice
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has been publicly reprimanded by the ABPI's Code of Practice Appeal Board, for a run of breaches relating to its failure to comply with an undertaking, by continuing to claim that its Vistabel/Botox (onabotulinumtoxin A) was clinically more potent than Merz' product Bocouture/Xeomin (incobotulinumtoxin A).
Merz claimed that at a meeting, and through one of its representatives, Allergan continued to misrepresent data relating to the relative potencies of the two rival medicines, despite rulings in previous cases that it should not do so.
Source: Pharmatimes December 17th

item.title: Valeant Adds Solta Medical in its Aesthetic Portolio
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: With the $250M acquisition of Solta Medical, Valeant will access to products used in procedures such as skin rejuvenation, skin tightening and body contouring.
Solta's leading aesthetic devices are a natural fit with Valeant's facial injectables, professional skin care products and physician dispensed products.
Financial: Valeant will acquire all of the outstanding common stock of Solta Medical, Inc. for $2.92 per share in cash, which represents a 40% premium to Solta's closing share price on December 13, 2013, the last trading day prior to announcement, or a transaction value of approximately $250 million.
Timelines: the transaction is expected to close Q1:14
Business: Solta designs, develops, manufactures, and markets energy-based medical device systems for aesthetic applications.
Products:
  • Thermage CPT system that provides non-invasive treatment options using radiofrequency energy for skin tightening
  • Fraxel repair system for use in dermatological procedures requiring ablation, coagulation, and resurfacing of soft tissue;
  • Clear + Brilliant system to improve skin texture and help prevent the signs of aging skin;
  • Liposonix system that destroys unwanted fat cells resulting in waist circumference reduction.
2012 Total Sales: approx. $145M.
Source: Valeant

item.title: CAM2029 To Be Developed For Both Acromegaly & Carcinoid Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During a recent French gastroenterology congress M Pavel (NET KOL) spoke about two new galenic forms of octreotide, refering to Camurus CAM2029, in-licensed by Novartis and oral octreotide in-licensed by Roche from Chiasma.
Thanks to Caroline Sert (Franchise Medical Advisor) & Jean-Francois Mocho (Franchise Marketing) we have accees to some of the slides that were presented.
M Pavel explained that few data are available as yet in the public domain. She spoke about phI/II data and about CAM2029 having 5-7 times the bioavailability of Sandostatin LAR. Pavel acknowledged that development will be for both acromegaly and NET (carcinoid syndrome) and that development will start in 2014 (no precise date defined).
Slides presented on Octreolin were similar to what have been presented at other congresses.
Nothing was mentioned about non-functioning NET or pasireotide.

item.title: GSK Increases Stake in its Indian Business and Announces Measures on its Marketing Practices
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GSK has offered to acquire an additional 24.2% stake in its Indian business for around $1bln. Management sees India as a strategic opportunity for the future, "particularly the volume opportunity". In parallel, the company has announced several measures regarding sales practices, which are part of a "broad effort to improve transparency" and not "related to its Chinese problems".
GSK said it will:
- stop paying doctors to promote its products at events
- still pay fees to doctors carrying out company-sponsored clinical research, advisory activities and market research
- stop payments to healthcare professionals for attending medical conferences (by the start of 2016)
- remove individual sales targets for its marketing staff (a new compensation system will be implemented by early 2015)
Markets pharmaceuticals and vaccines in respiratory, cardiovascular, oncology anti-infectives and dermatology.
2012 turnover: $421M
Source: FirstWord; ThomsonOne

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Theratechnologies To Pursue US Commercialisation Of Its Product
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Theratechnologies Inc., a biopharmaceutical company has agreed to terminate its collaboration and licensing agreement with EMD Serono in order to regain US commercialisation rights for tesamorelin a synthetic form of growth-hormone-releasing hormone which is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of proposed agreement, EMD Serono agreed to terminate its collaboration and licensing agreement with Theratechonologies in consideration of an early termination fee of US$20m payable over a five-year period starting on the first anniversary of the closing date. Starting in 2016, Theratechnologies will also pay an undisclosed, increasing royalty based on annual net sales. Royalties will be paid until a cumulative aggregate amount is reached or until January 1, 2024, the first of these events to occur.
Consequences Of The Deal
As a result of the termination of licensing agreement, Theratechnologies will regain all commercialization rights for Egrifta in the US and will be responsible for all operations in the US relating to Egrifta, including the conduct of the post-approval
The transaction represents a cornerstone of the Company’s business plan to maximize the commercial potential for Egrifta in the United States and elsewhere. By regaining rights to Egrifta it will have full control over a product it knows intimately.”
.

item.title: Auxilium Doses First Patient In Ph2b Frozen Shoulder Symdrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As flagged last week, Auxillium has now initiated a 300 patients phIIb frozen-shoulder study with its collagenase clostridium histolyticum (CCH) Xiaflex, an interesting development programme to monitor in light of Ipsen's development of Toxin E for rotator cuff injuries.
What Is Frozen-Shoulder Study (FSS)
FSS can be a prolonged, painful condition of the shoulder in which increased capsular collagen thickening and subsequent capsular contraction in the shoulder joint is thought to cause a loss of range of motion in the shoulder and pain. The condition is believed to affect approximately two to five percent of the general adult population and the full duration of the disease can last from approximately one year to up to 3.5 years. Some cases never completely resolve. The majority of cases are currently managed conservatively with prolonged physical therapy and occasionally with steroid injections. It is estimated that approximately 300,000 cases of FSS are diagnosed annually and approximately 10 percent are treated with an invasive intervention such as surgery or manipulation under anesthesia on an annual basis.
New Study Design
The Phase 2b study is a double-blind, placebo-controlled study of the safety and efficacy of CCH for the treatment of Stage 2 (frozen stage) unilateral idiopathic FSS. The study will enroll approximately 300 adult men and women at approximately 35 sites in the U.S. and Australia. Subjects will be randomized 3:1 to receive CCH or placebo and will receive up to three ultrasound-guided injections of study drug. Each injection will be separated by a minimum of 21 days. All subjects will also perform home shoulder exercises after the first injection.
In a prior Auxilium Phase 2a FSS study, both the 0.58mg (1mL) and 0.58mg (2mL) dosing arms showed statistically significant improvements.
The Phase 2b study's primary endpoint is the change (degrees) from baseline to the Day 95 follow-up visit in active forward flexion in the affected shoulder compared to placebo. Patients will also be assessed using the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Scale for function and pain as well as additional patient reported outcome measures. Safety assessments will be made during all study visits and immunogenicity testing will be performed at screening and at the end of the study.
Company Perception
FSS is viewed by Auxillium as a condition with no approved therapies and limited treatment options. Innovative treatment approaches such as CCH, if approved by the FDA, may allow patients quicker relief from limits in range of motion and associated pain.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Richter as acquired 51% stake in Brazil's NextPharma to register and distribute its female HC products in the South American countries. Richter also said it had secured an option to buy the remaining 49% of the company.
Milestones
Next Pharma, a private company founded in 2010, would register and establish a sales network for Richter's female healthcare products, such as its Esmya medicine for the treatment of uterine myoma.
NextPharma Network
Large private and public hospitals, retail chains as well as government agencies in Brazil.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Trial Design
Recruitment: n=200
Completion date: Nov 2015 / Sept 2016
Doses: 24U; 48U; 72U; 96U
Administration / Duration: im injection to the bilateral masseter muscle on D1 and retreatment at D180 if applicable.
Location: Canada

item.title: New Ph2 Trial With Teva's Huntexil for Huntington
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pridopidine 45mg, 67.5mg, 90mg, and 112.5mg will be assessed twice-daily vs placebo for the symptomatic treatment of Huntington's Disease. PE will determine change from baseline in Unified Huntington's Disease Rating Scale-Total Motor Score (UHDRS-TMS) at week 26.
Background
Teva is engaged in the development of pridopidine (Huntexil, ASP2314, ACR 16).
The drug candidate is in Ph3 for the treatment of motor disorders including Huntington's disease.
In September 2012, Teva announced that it has concluded an Asset Transfer Agreement with NeuroSearch A/S to purchase all rights, assets and obligations relating to Huntexil.
Trial Design
Recruitment: n=400
Start date: Jan 2014 - Jan 2015 / Feb 2015
Location: EU /US
Source: NCT02006472

Comments
On April 24h Teva announced the enrollment of the first patient in the Pride-HD study. To be noted, the completion date has been delayed to March 2015, and locations expanded to global from EU/US.
Professor G. Bernhard Landwehrmeyer, M.D., Ph.D, FRCP, and professor of neurology, Ulm University Hospital, Germany will be the lead study investigator.
About the Drug
Pridopidine is an investigational, oral, small molecule being developed for the symptomatic treatment of Huntington’s disease (HD). Teva intends to design and complete new clinical studies of pridopidine to assess its potential for symptomatic relief of HD. Earlier clinical studies of pridopidine conducted in the U.S., EU and Canada in patients with HD indicate a significant treatment effect on an important secondary endpoint, Total Motor Score (TMS).
In previous studies, where doses up to 45 mg bid were tested, pridopidine was well tolerated with an adverse event profile similar to placebo, and treatment with pridopidine was not associated with worsening of disease signs and symptoms.

item.title: GTx Plans Regulatory Meeting With The FDA To Define Pathway For nmCRPC Approval For GTx-756
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GTx has announced a poster presentation on its SARM Enobosarm as a potential treatment for Androgen Recptor-Positive Breast Cancer at the upcoming SABC congress. The drug is currently being evaluated in phII study for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer. Meanwhile, a phII study with GTx-758 in patients with mCRPC is ongoing with the goal being to develop the drug as the first secondary hormonal therapy in men, who have non-metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer nmCRPC.
The Capesaris Program
The GTx-758 phase 2 study was originally designed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of three doses of the drug; 125 milligrams, 250 milligrams, and 500 milligrams, oral daily dose. The primary endpoint of the study is the proportion of patients with a greater than 50% reduction from baseline in serum PSA by day 90.

Other key endpoints include, free testosterone levels, sex hormone binding globulin levels, and total testosterone levels in the study subjects. Prostate cancer progression is also being monitored. In addition, the clinical studies evaluating the ability of GTx-758 to treat certain estrogen deficiency side effects associated with androgen deprivation therapy such as hot flashes, bone loss and insulin resistance.

After reviewing data collected to date from the 125 milligram dosing arm, showing the ability of the drug to substantially increase sex hormone binding globulin and lower free testosterone, the clinical protocol was recently amended to eliminate the third dosing arm of 500 milligrams originally designed for the study and to increase the number of subjects to be involved in the 125 milligram and 250 milligram dosing arms to 38 subjects per arm.

The number of subjects per arm was increased to provide greater confidence in the safety of GTx-758 and to date no evidence of venous thromboembolic events or SAEs has been seen. Enrollment in the 125 milligram cohort is ongoing and assuming there continues to be no unacceptable incidents of venous thromboembolic events observed in patients in this cohort, GTx will then make the decision whether to proceed with dosing of the 250 milligram cohort.

GTx noted that when primary androgen deprivation therapy fails, the majority of patients develop non-metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer nmCRPC for which there are no approved secondary hormonal therapies.

GTx-758 Unique MOA Compared To Androgen Antagonists

GTx believes GTx can offer a unique secondary hormonal treatment option for men with nmCRPC. Other agents under development basically have the same mechanism of action as androgen receptor antagonist, and only have activity against the androgen receptor signaling pathway in prostate cancer cells, as it means to prevent metastatic progression. As an oral estrogen receptor agonist, GTX-758 is viewed as a new chemical entity with a unique drug mechanism.

GTx is positoining GTx-758 as a drug that not only affects the androgen receptor signaling pathway in prostate cancer cells by maximally suppressing circulating free testosterone, but also through its estrogenic effects provides the potential to improve bone quality by decreasing bone turnover.

Objective Positioning - Preferred Secondary Hormonal Therapy For nmCRPC

GTx is stating that bone-only agents such as bisphosphonates and denosomab have been shown to prevent bone metastatic disease, and treat skeletal related events in patients – excuse me, in prostate and other cancers. With a dual mechanism to prevent metastatic disease that is directly by reducing available free testosterone to prostate cancer cells, and indirectly by improving bone quality, to make the bone environment more resistant metastases, GTx-758 could thererfore, it claims, become a preferred secondary hormonal therapy for men with non-metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer.

Moreover, by replacing estrogen, the drug may also provide the pro-estrogenic benefits to improve other estrogen deficiency side effects commonly associate with primary, androgen deprivation therapy, such as hot flashes, bone loss in fractures, and metabolic syndrome in insulin resistance.

Next Steps

GTx plans to meet with FDA to discuss data from its ongoing Phase 2 clinical study, and a proposal to develop GTx-758 as the first secondary hormonal therapy in men, who have nmCRPC.

Its short-term objective is to complete the current Phase 2 safety and dose finding clinical study in metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer patients. Its regulatory objective is to find a way forward with the regulatory agency that will allow the grou to use an earlier endpoint like progression free survival (PFS) rather than OS as the clinical benefit endpoint required for approval in men with nmCRPC.

source: http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=148196&p=irol-calendarPast

Combination of ScinoPharm's API and Foresee's stabilized injectable formulation holds all the card to start playing the FOPs game.
The completion of the Changshu plant is an important milestone for ScinoPharm as it is the first API production plant to be built in accordance with the latest GMP requirements announced by the China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA).

item.title: France's TC Grants Reimbursement to Xtandi
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Transparency Commission (TC) of the Higher Authority on Healthcare (HAS) in France has provided a favourable opinion for the reimbursement of Astellas 's Xtandi (enzalutamide). In particular, the drug is approved for the treatment of adult men with mCRPC in patients previously treated with a docetaxel-containing drug. The TC has proposed a reimbursement rate of 100%.
The decision was taken on the basis of the assessment of the clinical value of the drug (Service Médical Rendu, SMR) which was rated "important".
In addition, the TC has also assessed that Xtandi brings a moderate improvement to medical benefit (ASMR III rating).
The full reimbursement decision is attached (in French).
Full reimbursement is generally granted under the French system to innovative and expensive drugs that obtain an important SMR rating. The effectiveness of the drug has been assessed through data of the Phase III AFFIRM trial which evaluated efficacy and tolerability of Xtandi against a placebo arm. The reimbursement decision has considered Johnson & Johnson (US)'s Zytiga (abiraterone acetate) a valid comparator and has assigned Xtandi the same ASMR rating.
In addition, the TC decision to grant Xtandi an ASMR rating of III will ensure Astellas the opportunity to maintain over the next five years a price level higher than the lowest price applied in the four main European markets – the European-level price guarantee. However, odds for success for Astellas to secure sales growth for Xtandi in the French market will also be influenced by the competition of other treatment approved for the same indications such as Zytiga. The drug has been approved by the European Commission in June 2013.
Source: IHS Global Insight

item.title: Roche "On the heels of cancer: biomarkers and combination therapies"
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a press release issued today, Roche has highlighted its activities in the cancer biomarker area and how these are likely to result in greater use of combination therapies than is the case today. Behind this is the significant advances being made in next generation sequencing, something Dr Attard (Royal Marsden Uk) alluded to in a recent interview regarding developments in the prostate cancer market. He suggested such developments will ultimately change the treatment paradigm within 5-8 years.

On the heels of cancer: biomarkers and combination therapies

To adapt anti-cancer treatments as much as possible to an individual patient and his or her disease, guiding biomarkers are needed. What are we doing now at Roche in that area? What will new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches look like?
Answers were given at the first Oncology Biomarker Symposium in Basel in October and can be found in an interview with its organizer Astrid Kiermaier, Associate Director Oncology Biomarker development:
Nearly all pharmaceutical companies are doing biomarker research now. Are we at Roche /Genentech really a leader in the field?
Yes! We start with biomarker discovery very early in research and continue through development of a potential drug and it’s registration. Currently about 70 % of our anti-cancer drug candidates in clinical development are being developed with a companion diagnostic – a tool, telling doctors which patient are highly likely to benefit from a drug. That’s far above average of the pharmaceutical industry.
How are cancer patients being diagnosed today?
Tumour tissue is used for most cancer classification and the therapy decisions that follow. Several methods are used to detect the presence and levels of proteins in that tissue that correlate with disease subtypes and that are predictive for drug benefit. In addition, we collect blood plasma to extract genetic material from tumours, that means, DNA that is released into the blood stream from tumour cells. Analysis of this circulating DNA allows characterisation of mutations associated with response or resistance further informing patient care.
What will the cancer diagnostics of tomorrow look like?
Technology platforms that can assess many biomarkers at the same time for example next generation sequencing, are starting to enter the field and are expected to supersede single marker analysis via classical methods over the next few years. This is a real leap forward both in terms of the information we get, but also in light of the limited tissue available from cancer patients. Future developments in both therapeutic and diagnostics will be driven primarily by an increased understanding of the signalling or immune pathways that are inappropriately regulated in cancer patients.
Will pathway-based therapies instead of organ-specific therapies be the consequence?
While pathway specific therapies would be ideal, biology teaches us differently. First, it is important to understand whether a certain pathway really drives the cancer. Even though we once believed that treating a cancer based on genotype would be the future of cancer medicine, we have since learned that anatomic origin really matters. For example: One of our drugs is highly effective as a monotherapy in malignant melanoma carrying a V600 mutation in the BRAF oncogene. But there is little or no activity in the context of this mutation in colorectal cancer. Research is needed to decipher why. Is the V600 mutation a driver in colorectal cancer, a “passenger” or do we need to hit two targets at the same time? Our exploratory analyses are aimed at addressing these important questions.
Will there be more combination treatments in future?
Yes, if treatments only intervene at one node of a signalling cascade, other signalling pathways can still be activated, bypass the first blockade enabling uncontrolled cell growth, and making the treatment ineffective. Again, it is important to understand the biology of the diseases we aim to treat, the pathways that are driving tumours, the cross-talk between pathways and how this may impact treatment outcome. These questions are integral to our biomarker programmes.
What are immunotherapies in oncology?
They aim to enhance or re-vitalize the body’s natural immune response so that it can destroy tumour cells. Tumours often develop mechanisms to evade the body’s own immune system that would otherwise destroy cancerous cells.
How does biomarker research help in developing these therapies?
Biomarker teams try to understand the immune cell repertoire found in the patient’s body and tumour. Furthermore, we would like to identify mechanisms to restore or to generate an anti-tumour immune response. Biomarkers are needed to fully appreciate the complexity of human cancer immune biology and to identify patients most likely to benefit from immunotherapies.
Why aren’t all potential anti-cancer drugs being co-developed with a companion diagnostic?
Our overall objective is to co-develop all our drug candidates with a companion diagnostic. However, the biology of the diseases may be too complex to enable us to identify a biomarker that qualifies for a companion diagnostic at the start of phase III. In those cases biomarker research is continued throughout phase III and post registration. In addition, some examples of our drugs are very active in specific diseases - reducing the need for a companion diagnostic.
How are biomarkers used beyond the development of companion diagnostics?
Biomarker studies can help to understand disease biology and to identify patient subgroups with the highest unmet medical need. Furthermore, biomarkers can help to understand the outcome of combination therapies and how to rationally design drug combination therapies. Understanding the development of resistance against cancer therapies is another goal of biomarker research. Last but not least, a good new biomarker tells us much earlier than traditional clinical assessments like x-ray imaging whether a drugs work.
Key success factors for an ideal companion diagnostic?

A companion diagnostic should be easy to use, accurate, standardized, broadly available, cost effective and, importantly, validated in clinical trials. Ideally, the companion diagnostic is co-developed with the drug and clinically validated prospectively enabling regulatory approvals and reimbursement decisions.

Source: roche.com

item.title: Dose-Response Study of Xeomin® for Spasticity due to CP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: XARA is a Ph3 prospective, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, paralell-group, dose-response study to determine whether injections of Xeomin® into muscles of one or both arms alone or in combination with injections into one or both legs are effective and safe in treating children/adolescents (age 2-17 years) with spasticity due to CP. PE will evaluate change from baseline in Ashworth Scale in the primary clinical target pattern, i.e. elbow flexors or wrist flexors.
Recruitment: n=344
Start date: Jan 2014 Completion date: March 2016 / April 2017
Dosage
IncobotulinumtoxinA (8 Units per kg body weight)IncobotulinumtoxinA (6 Units per kg body weight)IncobotulinumtoxinA (2 Units per kg body weight)
Location: USA; Argentina; Canada; Mexico
Source: NCT02002884

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Daewoong inked a contract worth approx KRW 100 bln (US$94 million) with global aesthetic company PharmaVital. Clinical trials are unnecessary in Latin America and Daewoong will enter the approval process (1.5-2 years) immediately. NABOTA will be released gradually from 2014 to 2016 in Latin America. Of note, PharmaVital markets Siax (Medy-tox botulinum toxin A).
15 LatAm countries, including the largest markets: Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Brazil.
Marketing timelines: from 2014 to 2016
Supply contract: PharmaVital will supply NABOTA for 5 years after its roll-out in each country.
http://www.pharmavital.net/web/
HQ: Panama
Products: Siax; Bioage; Perfectha;
- export contract (KRW 300 bln) with Evolus - (see Neurology7191: Evolus to Sell Daewoong's Botulinum Toxin (Nabota) in the US and EU Markets).
Daewoong secured domestic marketing approval of NABOTA on November 29. The drug is scheduled to be released in early- 2014 after preparation for marketing and production.

item.title: Reorganisation of Almirall Operations in EU Affects 250 Jobs in Spain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Although Spain is one of the top five pharmaceutical markets in Europe, the impact of a number of cost-containment measures and in particular the implementation of the reference-pricing system, with its most updated version in March 2011 has been increasingly affecting profit growth. Amirall has reported that economic decisions made by health authorities in EU have hit the introduction and uptake of new medicines. In Spain where the pharma market has been contracting for the past 4 years, the company's restructuring will affect 250 positions.
Spain: YTD June 2013 sales decreased by 17.3% to €134.1M (vs €162.0M).
Recently Actavis mandated Rotschild to advise on the sale of its EU units (Itally, Spain, France, Germany, and the NL).
Sources: FirstWord; IHS;

item.title: Avanir Provides Pipeline Update
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Yesterday at the Piper Jaffray H/C conference, Avanir gave an update on its strong revenue growth +100% and its pipeline, which will now focus on its 2nd generation, patent-protected deuterated dextromethorpan. The indication focus will be behavioural & mood disorders plus multiple sclerosis and diabetic neuropathic pain. PhII MS pain data is due before the year-end.
Current Financial Progress
Commenting on the group's revenue development over the last year Keith Katkin President & CEO noted:-
"If you look at our last reported quarter with the quarter ending September 30, which happens to be our fiscal year end as well and look at what we've accomplished in fiscal 2013, it was really a tremendous year for the company. Over 100% growth in NUEDEXTA gross revenue in the year with $92.1 million in gross revenue. And if you just look at the business metrics or unit growth over the last quarter, quarter and a half, it's still strong. So you look at the quarter ended September 30, the sequential quarter-over-quarter growth in unit demand was 12%. You look at this quarter, the first seven weeks of this quarter over the first seven weeks of last quarter and we're up just shy of 10%."
Development Perspective
Keith Katkin elaborated on how dextromethorpan has a very interesting profile, modulating both sigma-1 and through NMDA two receptors it has talked a lot about. But how looking further, NUEDEXTA activates serotonin and norepinephrine, two receptors which play a significant role in a number of CNS products, many of which are approved for very large indications.
He stated, "we think about the therapeutic potential of dextromethorphan and we think about the pharmacology, we see tremendous amounts of potential use for dextromethorphan. So obviously, we're FDA-approved for pseudobulbar affect. But we really think given the pharmacology, we can be effective in mood and behavior disorders, in various types of pain, and also in movement disorders."
"So we've thought about our clinical development program, we've really focused in those three different areas, in the mood and behavior disorders. We've got pseudobulbar affect, plus we have an ongoing Phase II study in agitation, secondary to Alzheimer's disease. And we announced just a couple of weeks ago that we're going to start a Phase II study in treatment-resistant depression in the second half of 2014.
In the pain space, we have done a number of studies, both in diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain and in pain secondary to multiple sclerosis. We'll have data from our most recent trial in pain and multiple sclerosis by the end of this year. And then in movement disorders, we've got a levodopa-induced dyskinesias in Parkinson's patients study that's ongoing funded by the Michael J. Fox Foundation."
"We've designed our development program for NUEDEXTA with all of those potential applications in mind, and we look forward to getting started and get data over the few weeks and throughout 2014 as well."
"If you think about the evolution of a clinical program, we started in diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain. And then when we first got NUEDEXTA approved for pseudobulbar affect, we really – we thought that focusing the pain program on pain secondary to multiple sclerosis would be a good idea. We thought that would be a good idea for two reasons.
· One, because our intellectual property in pain was not as long as our intellectual property for PBA. But in pain secondary to multiple sclerosis, there's a possibility to get orphan drug status. And so, we've made a decision to move down that path.
· In addition, there were no approved therapies for treatment of central neuropathic pain secondary to multiple sclerosis.
"For all of those reasons, MS pain made a lot of sense for the company. Since initiating that program, we've in-licensed deuterated dextromethorphan. And deuterated dextromethorphan has really changed how we can think about the overall development program. It's got a very long intellectual property life through 2030. Also – the way the deuterated works is it actually allows us to significantly reduce the amount of quinidine in the second generation compound. So, what we've decided is that, going forward, we will definitely pursue diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain assuming we see a signal in the Phase II MS pain study."
Source: www.avanir.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Astellas Press Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has highlighted new therapeutic areas, current and future product strategy, outlined its multi-track R&D system, and presented recent figures on the pharma market, vision and changes.
The company is focused on maximazing value of new products and overcoming the upcoming of patent cliffs (generic versions of the Micardis family of hypertensives in 2017 H2, and the expiry of the US patent on Vesicare in 2018).
  • maximizing its OAB franchise (Vesicare; Mirabegron)
  • strengthening the oncology field (with additional XTANDI indications)
  • building on partnerships and marketing alliances (Amgen, MSD, Astellas BioPharma)
Life cycle management and continuous product rollout have been outlined as part as the strategy.
  • Field of skeletal muscle activation (in collboration with Cytokinetics)
  • Mitochondria related diseases (in collaboration with Mitokyne)
  • Regenerative drugs (external resources such as academia, biotech ...)
  • Vaccines (partnering)
- by utilizing more external capabilities and resources

item.title: IBS-D Ph2 of Lexicon's LX1033 Fails to Show Improvement Vs Placebo
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The primary endpoint of this study was the change in stool consistency averaged from baseline to day 28. All treatment groups, including placebo, showed significant improvements over time, yet differences between placebo and LX1033 in stool consistency were not statistically significant. The company noted there were positive trends on a separate, abdominal pain responder analysis at the highest dose. More information to come during the company R&D Day on Dec. 5th.
In this Phase 2 study of IBS-d, 373 patients were randomized to be treated for 28 days with either placebo or one of three different dose levels of LX1033 for 28 days, 1000 mg twice daily, 500 mg twice daily, and 500 mg three times daily.
The primary endpoint was the change from baseline in stool consistency as evaluated by the Bristol Stool Form Scale.
A key secondary endpoint was the change from baseline in abdominal pain, and other endpoints included the change in plasma 5-HIAA.
Source: Lexicon

item.title: Key Takeaways From the 2nd EU Congress on Endometriosis (Nov 28-30 in Berlin)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: More than 670 gynaecologists (vs 622 in 2012) from 51 countries (vs 43 last year) attended the congress. This year selected theme was deep-infiltrating endometriosis (DIE), a particular form of endometriosis that penetrates under the peritoneal surface. The congress mainly focused on live surgeries, a crosssection of current research areas and discussions of case studies, but did not provide new data/results on drugs. Thank to Patrick Cabri (Medical Director Uro-Onco Franchise), we have got feedback from the two only pharma representatives. Bayer opened the event with a three-module session focused on the challenges in the management of endometriosis, clinicial experience and evidence-based treatment with Visanne, and current controversies in the medical management of the condition. On the second day, Takeda's lunch symposium titled 'start of the art in endometriosis therapy' dealt with the role of GnRH agonists in the treatment of the condition.
Current classification (K. Biberoglu, Turkey) - Most widely used staging system for endometriosis is the revised American Society for reproductive Medicine (rASRM) classification system. Additional staging tools have been published but can only be seen as added classification. The fertility index (EFI) is one of those but is very subjective. Can only be used if goal of treatment is fertility. Brazil is preparing the AAGL classification which is only based on the surgical findings. Ideal tool does not exist yet. No clear conclusion from the author, still use the rASRM!
Mechanisms of pain in endometriosis (K. Vincent, GB) - Mechanism of pain is very complex. Chronic pain may alter the volume of some parts of the brains (thalamus for example). Body adaptation to chronic pain (this may explain the “low” score at VAS). It is important that pain management in endometriosis is initiated early.
A stepwise approach to management (N. Leyland, Canada) - Full explanation of the Canadian guidelines. Those guidelines recommend a stepwise approach to early medical treatment with the aim of delaying the need for surgery and primarly focusing on alleviating pain. Similar findings at the ESHRE guidelines 2013 and WES consensus 2011. Still open for discussion: what is the role of medical therapy in treatment of DIE?
Pathophysiology of endometriosis and rationale for progestin therapy (F. Petraglia, It) - Three theories on the appearance of endometriosis: one as retrograde migration of endometrial cells during menstruation, the second is the migration of those cells through the vascular bed in the uterus and the last and new is the migration of stem cells to the adjacent tissues. Visanne has pleiotropic effects (multiple targets) = stop proliferation as well as inflammation.
Visanne data (T. Faustmann, Bayer) - Presentation of main clinical and safety data by the head of Medical affairs Bayer. Additional clinical data from Japan has also been shown with the clear statement that a partner is performing those activities, with no direct involvement of Bayer. From Japan a publication is expected on the recurrence rate between Visanne and a GnRHa. No publication date yet.
Anti-inflammatory effects of Visanne: new data (M. Mueller, CH) - Presentation of interim data on some cytokines (from peritoneal fluid taken during surgery): Macrophage chemotactic factor-1 (MCP-1), Midkine and Glycodelin-A. All are potent inflammatory cytokines. Study compared placebo with Visanne and a GnRHa, both prescribed for 3 months before surgery. Significant reduction on cytokines levels for both products when compared to placebo, no difference between Visanne and GnRHa. In conclusion: Visanne has a potent anti-inflammatory effect, similar to GnRHa.
Real-world experience with Visanne (N. Leyland, Canada) - In Canada there is a long waiting list for operating rooms. Therefore drugs have been used during this period. The objective is to improve symptoms, not to improve the surgery! Bleeding under Visanne can be present but mostly during the first 3 months. Thereafter improvement. If the bleeding is still problematic 1 (or 2) dose(s) of GnRHa followed by Visanne thereafter is recommended. For DIE his experience is that Visanne reduce the lesion size by 30% if given 6 months pre-operatively. Visanne is a less expensive treatment as second-line treatment.
Specific comments from audience
1/ Has Visanne an effect on fibroma’s? - No data available. In Japan there might be some observations showing some volume reduction. No more info.
2/ Has Dienogest a contraceptive effect? - No studies as such. It could be used as off-label use but the intake has to be well planned. Due to compliance issues (forgetting an intake) it is recommended to use in addition a barrier method during the first 6 weeks.
Controversies in medical management of endometriosis
  • In Europe: +/- 14 Mio women suffer from endometriosis. Proportion of DIE (deep infiltrating endometriosis): 10% to 20%
  • DIE: only 30% of patients will have a recurrence after surgical intervention, often in the urinary tract (from 4.4% to 12% according to the literature).
  • Incomplete excisional surgery is the main cause of recurrence.
  • Surgery need specialized centers & trained gynecologists. It is also technically challenging.
  • Center of excellence in Europe: 600 centers only. Therefore waiting lists for surgery, leading to medical treatment necessity. Fact: Sometimes women feel good under medication that they postpone the surgery!
Pf. Chapron concluded this session highlighting the following:
  • Medical treatment is efficient to treat DIE
  • Progesterone receptors in smooth muscles surrounding the endometriotic cells have been shown
  • Surgery and medical treatment are required and to be initiated as earlier as possible.
  • Not all patients are well surgically treated therefore the need for medical treatment.
Causes of subfertility: Dyspareunia; Phagocytosis increase; Change in peritoneal fluid; Gametes transportation; Disturbed ovum pick-up.
Maturation of oocyte in endometriotic milieu lead to less implantation rate/pregnancy (shown through endometriotic donor to no endometriosis receptor study)
Role of GnRHa
  • If surgery only: 80% improvement in pain but recurrence of 20% in 5 years
  • Reduction of recurrence rates (Hemming, reprod med 1998)
  • Recurrence rate: 50% after 12 months for DIE, less for SUP or OMA
  • If surgery done just before menses higher recurrence rate
  • Intermittent GnRHa treatment: can lead to 10 months off treatment. Ideal for long term treatment.
Will be published in the Journal of Endometriosis and Pelvic Pain Disorders within 3 months.

item.title: Findings from Two Ph3 with Fampridine-SR for Spasticity in SCI
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The results which have been recently published in Spinal Cord show that Fampridine-SR was well tolerated. No significant differences were observed between treatment groups for the primary end points of Ashworth score and SGI. The overall results of previous studies and those reported here suggest that further evaluation of fampridine-SR may be warranted in patients with SCI.
Study Details
- design
2 randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials. NCT00041717 NCT01683838
- recruitment the populations were 212 and 203 patients in the 2 studies.
- locations
US & Canada - methods Patients with incomplete chronic SCI were randomized to twice daily fampridine-SR 25 mg or placebo, with a 2-week single-blind placebo run-in, a 2-week titration, 12 weeks of stable dosing, 2 weeks of downward titration and 2 weeks of untreated follow-up.
Source: Spinal Cord advance online publication 12 November 2013; doi: 10.1038/sc.2013.137

item.title: Allergan Closes the Sale of its Obesity Intervention Business for Up to $110M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Apollo Endosurgery, Inc., a developer of medical devices for endoscopic surgical procedures, has acquired the obesity intervention division of Allergan (the LAP-BAND® adjustable gastric banding system, and the ORBERA™ intra-gastric balloon system).
The purchase price of up to $110 million includes an upfront cash payment of $75 million, a minority equity interest in Apollo by Allergan of $15 million, and up to $20 million in additional contingent consideration to be paid upon achievement of certain regulatory and sales milestones.
Allergan announced the transaction during its Q3 earnings on Oct 29.
Source: Allergan; Apollo Endosurgery

IQWiG also reported that Xtandi improved OS in patients without visceral metastases and delayed onset of complications and improve dpain in patients with and without visceral metastases.
Comments are due Dec.23, with a final benefit assessment from G-BA expected in February.

item.title: Results Of New Allergan Sponsored US Spasticity Survey
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The National Stroke Association and Allergan recently conducted a US survey to understand the true impact of this condition on stroke survivors and their caregivers. According to the findings, 70 percent (n=300) of stroke survivors living with spasticity and their caregivers rank spasticity as one of the top three symptoms impacting their life post-stroke, ranking second only to paralysis. Yet, close to 50 percent of stroke survivors and their caregivers are unaware of the available treatment options.
Commenting on the results of the survey Dr. Elliot J. Roth, Medical Director of the Patient Recovery Unit and Attending Physician, Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago; Professor & Chairman, PM&R, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine states in the press realease "Spasticity is a disabling condition, but, oftentimes, patients are either uncomfortable or too overwhelmed to discuss it with their physician. The focus after someone has experienced a stroke is so commonly on preventing a second stroke that rehabilitation goals are covered in broad terms. This can leave patients and their caregivers feeling unprepared for a larger discussion about the post-stroke symptoms they may be experiencing, including spasticity. It’s critical that patients and caregivers understand that even if a person has been experiencing spasticity for years, in many cases, there are ways to help manage the condition,”
Although 95 percent (n=780) of physicians surveyed believe spasticity has a moderate to severe impact on their patients’ lives, approximately 31 percent of neurologists and 27 percent of primary care physicians who treat stroke survivors focus their efforts on preventing a secondary stroke versus discussing physical complications like spasticity.
For more information about spasticity, including an interactive discussion guide patients are referred to a website which potentially may be sponsored by Allergan www.SpasticityAfterStroke.com.
Source: Yuma Arizona News

item.title: Progenics To Relaunch Azedra Registrational Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Progenics has announced it is resuming a phase 2b clinical study of safety and efficacy of a novel targeted radiotherapy, Azedra™, in patients suffering from pheochromocytomas. Existing options for these rare endocrine tumors that form in the adrenal glands can fail to result in effective disease treatment.
Commenting on Azedra the trials lead investigator Daniel Pryma, M.D., Assistant Professor of Radiology and Nuclear Medicine/Molecular Imaging Modality Chief of the Department of Radiology at the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine, said, "I have seen in my own research evidence that Azedra is a promising agent for the treatment of metastatic pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma — two orphan oncology indications with tragically unmet needs. There currently are no medications approved specifically to treat pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas."
Background
Azedra originally was developed by Progenics' Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals (MIP) subsidiary, which commenced the phase 2b study under a 2009 Special Protocol Assessment (SPA) with the US FDA.
The compound also has Orphan Drug and Fast Track designations. In late 2010 MIP suspended the trial, with enrollment two-thirds complete, to seek additional funding. Progenics, which acquired MIP in early 2013, plans for patient recruitment to continue after making drug supply manufacturing arrangements for the trial.
Next Steps
Following a successful completion of this phase 2b study, Progenics intends to submit a New Drug Application (NDA) and request priority review to receive FDA action on the application within six months instead of the standard ten.
Azedra may also have utility in treating neuroblastomas and other neuroendocrine diseases.
Hagop Youssoufian, M.Sc., M.D., Executive Vice President of Research and Development for Progenics, said, "Azedra has the potential to be the first approved treatment for pheochromocytomas. Our team is energized by this opportunity to potentially bring a treatment option with improved dosing, safety and efficacy to patients suffering with these devastating conditions."
Source: www.progenics.com

item.title: Nanomedicine Platform Takes A Leap Forward
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:BIND Therapeutics, a clinical nanomedicine platform company has announced that the company's co-founders have successfully engineered targeted nanoparticles to cross biological barriers, potentially broadening future therapeutic applications for its platform. Its previously announced Accurins, have to date has been partnered with a number of companies and its proprietary nanoengineered docetaxel BIND-014 is in phII for the treatment of mCRPC (data from a recent presentation highlighting its activity is shown below).
Published Paper
The data has been published in a paper entitled, "Transepithelial Transport of Fc-Targeted Nanoparticles by the Neonatal Fc Receptor for Oral Delivery," published in the November 27, 2013 online issue of Science Translational Medicine,
The Key Discovery
BIND's co-founders Robert Langer Sc.D., and Omid Farokhzad, M.D., have demonstrated the ability to enhance the surface properties of the nanoparticle to target the neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn), a transport receptor present on the plasma membrane of cells that form many of the biological barriers in the body including: intestinal epithelial barrier, pulmonary epithelial barrier, blood-brain barrier, fetal-placental barrier, and blood-ocular barrier.
The FcRn function is to shuttle Immunoglobulin G (IgG) molecules across biological barriers that are otherwise impermeable to IgG. Taking advantage of the biological properties of the FcRn as a model transcellular trafficking receptor, the investigators demonstrated for the first time, proof of concept in a preclinical model that targeted therapeutic nanoparticles can exploit biological transport pathways and gain access to biological compartments that are otherwise impermeable to nanoparticles and other macromolecules.
The FcRn-targeted nanoparticles were shown in an animal model to cross the intestinal epithelial barrier after oral administration and enter the systemic circulation, displaying an absorption efficiency that enabled uptake of therapeutic dose levels. As expected, the FcRn-mediated nanoparticle absorption was lost in animals deficient in FcRn expression. Using insulin as a model large molecular weight drug with minimal oral bioavailability, the FcRn-targeted nanoparticles were able to significantly increase insulin bioavailability resulting in plasma glucose modulation.
Credit Suisse H/C Conference Presentation
"

item.title: Sativex® Approved in Switzerland
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A full MA has been granted by the Swissmedic authorities for the treatment of moderate to severe spasticity in MS patients who have not responded adequately to other anti-spasticity medications.
Depending on completion of P&R procedures.
23 countries, including 17 in EU (on prescription in UK, Spain, Germany; Canada; Denmark, Norway, Israel, Austria, Poland, Sweden, Italy and Finland).
Launch currently in preparation for further 8 EU countries, as well as Australia, New Zealand and Kuwait.
Source: FirstWord

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lead Investigator Reports on Xofigo
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Chris Parker, the PI of ALSYMPCA trial and consultant clinical oncologist at the Royal Marsden hospital in London, provides his views on the radioactive nature of Xofigo.
Xofigo is an alpha-emitter, while current radiation therapies use beta-emitters such as barium and strontium.
Parker suggests that the limited usage of older radioactive therapies stems primarily from their lack of efficacy.
Xofigo provides an OS benefit, a QoL benefit, and benefit in terms of time to first skeletal-related event, and a much more favourable profile. " ... so to me, there's no comparison".
EU experience with radioactive therapies is broadly thought to be greater than in the US, due to less familiarity with radiotherapies among physicians in the country. Also, in the US a nuclear license is required to administer the drug.
UK perpsectives: Parker suggests that there will be little issue with how Xofigo is used in the UK.
  • 20 centers in the UK have already been involved in the ALSYMPCA study, and it would perharps require just 10 centers to cater for expected demand in the country.
Parker reports that "in the ALSYMPCA trial Xofigo was used in combination with a whole range of different hormone therapies, corticosteroids, oestrogens, anti-androgens, ketoconazole, and given the mechanism of actions, it is completely different to hormonal agents." He adds "I don't anticipate any problems, any difficulties in combining Xofigo with either abiraterone or enzalutamide".
Parket oulines it is " ... a particulalrly viable route given the safety profile of the drug" ... "toxicity of six cycles of Xofigo is remarkably low".
Source: FirstWord

item.title: Expanded Treatment Protocol of Pasireotide LAR for Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new study planned as an expanded treatment protocol to provide acromegalic patients access to pasireotide LAR while regulatory approval for pasireotide is sought.
Design
The ACCESS Ph4 trial is an open-label, multi-center, safety monitoring program for treating patients with SOM230 who have need to receive medical therapy.
Intervention
Pasireotide LAR will be administered intramuscularly (i.m.) every 28 days until pasireotide becomes commercially available and reimbursed or until 31 December 2015, whichever occurs first.
Location
approx. 26 sites in the US
Source: Please see @ NCT01995734

item.title: New Gastrin Antagonist Demonstrates Preliminary Proof Of Efficacy In Type I Gastric Carcinoid
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At this week's UKI NETs meeting, Andrew Moore from the University of Liverpool presented early clinical trial data on the gastrin CCK2 receptor antagonist netazepide in type-1 gastric NET. The small study in 8 patients demonstrated tumour regression and a good tolerability profile. The first clinical presentation on this product was made at ENETS 2012.
Netrazepide is being developed by a company called Trio Pharmaceuticals based in Sussex UK. It in-licensed the product from Ferring which had been previously developing the drug for gastroeoesophageal reflux disease. Ferring stopped development in 2005. In June 2007, orphan designation was granted by the EMEA to Trio Medicines for YF-476 for the treatment of gastric carcinoid, following a positive opinion by the COMP in April 2007
A copy of the trial protocol (attached) details the previous clinical development of this drug and shows that the drug is also being evaluated for
  • In 7/8 patients the number and or size of the NETs decreased (mean reduction in the size of the largest tumouir was 33%, mean reduction in tumour number 30%) but none showed a complete tumour response.
  • Serum chromagrainin A concentrations decreased in all patients during treatment, but fasting gastrin concentrations were unchanged.
  • Netazepide was well tolerated, caused no serious AEs and no cases of haematological, renal or hepatic toxicity
For previous data presented at ENETS by Helge Waldrum in 2012 please follow the link attached (see Endocrinology6889: ENETS Intelligence Part 3- Key Developments With Imaging, Translational Science & Notable Posters)
Source: UKI NETS Abstract Programme

Comments
CCK2 could be a potential target for peptide approach as well. One of the clinical investigator involved in this study would be Timothy Wang of Columbia University whom I met recently. He is interested in working with us as well.
  1. journal.pone.0076462.s002[1].pdf  (1,4 MB)
