item.title: Xenoport Investor Calls For The Resignation of CEO & New Strategy Focused On MS Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A shareholder in Xenoport has called for the resignation of its CEO and called for a shift in focus to the company's PhI RRMS drug XP23829 a pro-drug of monomethyl fumarate, a drug known as BG12 (TECFIDERA) launched by Biogen-Idecs for the treatment of RRMS. Interestingly, Xenoport recently highlighted some phI data with two different formulations of XP23829 (see below) which points to possible differentiation with one of the formulations in terms of dosing tolerability and patent claims or a potential me-too 505(b) (2) route to registration for the other.
The investor is claiming that Xenoport's Horizant gabapentin enacarbil, which is approved in the US to treat restless legs and to manage post herpetic neuralgia "will never be the commercial success we all wish it were" It suggest that the company should use its remaining cash to push forward with the development of XP23829 which could potentially address a massive commercial opportunity and would help the company to garner a significant partnering deal or the sale of the company.
Xenoport currrently has $93.4m in cash a recorded a six-month operating loss of $47.8m. In addition to poor sales of Horizant it has faced recent disappointment with its racemic baclofen which was in PhIII development for the treatment of spasticity.
XP23829 Trial Status
Ronald Barrett CEO in early September presented some limited phI data on XP23829.
First phI study
A repeat dose Phase 1 study of 829 tested Formulation 1 and Formulation 2 of 829 and had a TECFIDERA arm to allow for pharmacokinetic comparisons. Formulation 1 was designed to mimic the PK profile of TECFIDERA when dosed BID. And Formulation 2 was designed as a potential once a day dosage form.
Barrett stated "We believe that we can now put to rest any questions about the ability of 829 to effectively deliver MMF into the systemic circulation. At approximately equimolar doses of 829 Formulation 1 and TECFIDERA, we observed essentially identical PK profiles of MMF in plasma. In both cases, there was a lag before MMF appeared in the plasma and then there was a sharp peak of MMF. Remarkably, the mean Cmax and the mean AUC of MMF for Formulation 1 and TECFIDERA were within 2% of each other.
"What are the potential implications of these results? We believe these data provide evidence that Formulation 1 could be bioequivalent to TECFIDERA when it comes to MMF in plasma. This may be an important element if we decide to pursue and get agreement from the FDA on a potential 505(b)(2) route for the approval in relapsing-remitting MS." "Assuming we would need to do a formal bioequivalent study, we believe that the probability for success will be high based on these results. Therefore, we believe that Formulation 1 could be a candidate for streamline development as a twice a day product for MS. Also, given the successful studies of TECFIDERA in psoriasis, we believe that the PK similarity of Formulation 1 makes the likelihood of success in psoriasis high."
"So, what about Formulation 2? We're equally excited by these results since we think this formulation holds promise for a differentiated product profile. At an 800 mg dose of 829, dosed once a day, which is approximately equimolar to the approved TECFIDERA daily dose, we get a mean daily AUC within about 25% of the twice a day TECFIDERA while maintaining a lower Cmax despite giving the full daily dose at a single time." "I want you to keep in mind that these are mean values that were determined in separate cohorts of patients. There is significant overlap in the AUCs in individual subjects between these two groups. So, it is not clear that these AUCs are really different and particularly whether they are different enough to be clinically meaningful."
"The more sustained exposure to MMF observed for Formulation 2 was distinct from Formulation 1 and TECFIDERA, both of which had a shorter duration of MMF exposure. As a result, we believe that Formulation 2 could potentially support once a day dosing in MS and/or psoriasis." "So, in summary, we're quite pleased with the MMF PK profiles produced by Formulation 1 and Formulation 2 after repeated dosing. These results will allow us to select doses for future studies"
Second phI study & Toxicity Data Commenting on the 2nd phI study Barrett continued "Our second Phase 1 study examined metabolism and disposition of two versions of radiolabel 829, one version with the radiolabel in the fumarate portion of the molecule and a second version with the radiolabel in the promoiety portion of the molecule. As expected, the metabolism and disposition for the fumarate-labeled version of 829 was similar to what has been publicly reported for dosing of DMF labeled in the same location as the fumarate."
"For the promoiety-labeled version of 829, virtually all the recovered radioactivity was found in urine as expected from our animal studies."
"Finally, we have now completed 13-week tox studies of 829 in mouse, rat and primate. Each study included a DMF group. The adverse effects in the 13-week toxicology studies with 829 were similar to the effects in the DMF control group except for fewer and less severe adverse effects in the stomach after dosing of 829. These results support a conclusion that the observed adverse effects of 829 were attributable to exposure to MMF, the common active metabolite of DMF and 829."
Competition & Patents
Continuing Barrett stated, "let me remind you that with the success of TECFIDERA, there is – already is and will likely be more formidable competition to develop a best-in-class second-generation fumarate product. We believe our new studies have generated important new intellectual property. And we're in the process of assessing what aspects of the new information might be patentable."
"As mentioned in this press release, we have been working on our novel fumarate program for more than five years. We filed 15 patent applications to protect 829 and broader aspects of MMF prodrugs. We believe we're in a leadership position. We don't believe it's good business practice to provide a lot of details that might be useful to competitors."
"So, in summary, we believe we completed a very successful series of studies."
Interesting points to arise from the Q/A regarding regulatory pathway and patents Xenoport hopes to have meetings with both the Neurology Products Division and with the Derm Division in the fourth quarter to discuss the pathway forward.
Barrett noted that one important question is to the relationship between PK and adverse events with the first in human study demonstating a difference between the two formulations with regard to flushing. Xenoport has apparently decided to put this out in the public domain exactly what the results are as it is in the process of analyzing whether there's any intellectual property here that could be subject to patent filings.
Questioned as to whether management are hopeful that either Formulation 1 or 2 could be superior to TECFIDERA in terms of flushing and GI? Barrett responded "Absolutely" Questioned about an overalll pathway forward he stated "Understand that there really are two potential high level things that we're considering. There's the go-it-alone strategy, what would we do next if we're not with a partner and then what would we do if we're with a partner. And what we've been trying to do, and maybe I haven't been articulating this as well as we should, is to create optionality for the possible progression forward."
"So, we have been, as you know, pursuing both the Formulation 1 and Formulation 2. Formulation 1 presents the opportunity to do the 505(b)(2) pathway potentially and would be a much more streamlined development path. Formulation 2 has the potential for, in our view at this point, differentiation on both dosing frequency as well as potentially on side effects. So, that's a different development path. So, we want to continue our dialogue with potential partners, get feedback from the FDA and make the decision. And, as I said earlier, by the end of the year, I think we'll be able to articulate a – what we're doing next on our own strategy if we're not partnered by them." One last question focused on whether if he 505(b)(2) sort of me-too to TECFIDERA route was chosen, would Xenoport run into Biogen's dosing patent? Barrett replied, "So, we do not dose 480 mgs of DMF. So, on a strict literal infringement, the answer is no. You are correct in suggesting that we would have to do a patent certification under 505(b)(2). And we don't believe that we would infringe. Obviously, that would be subject to potential litigation with the Orange Book listed – against the Orange Book listed patents. We don't believe that we would infringe those patents."
Source: www.xenoport.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Funding for Zytiga and Xgeva Moved from Government to Hospital Budget in Norway
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Reimbursement for J&J' Zytiga (abiraterone acetate), and Amgen's bone cancer drug Xgeva (denosumab) will be provided through hospital funding in 2014, under Norway's 2014 budget proposal.
According to the Norwegian medical newspaper Dagens Medisin, the proposal also foresees that funding responsibility for new cancer drugs that are alternatives to those already reimbursed from hospital budgets are moved from the government to the hospitals' funding responsibility. The Health Directorate proposed that competent authorities should be enabled to make a decision about which drugs the provision applies to.
Significance
Earlier this year, the Norwegian Health Directorate decided to exclude Zytiga from the guidelines for cancer treatment. The decision was that Zytiga was not recommended as standard treatment in Norwegian hospitals, further to an evaluation of the cost effectiveness.
According to a study by the University of Oslo, it appears that patients' access to these drugs was not jeopardised by the transfer of the funding to hospital budgets. This represents positive news for the patients, as well as manufacturers. Financing of treatment through the hospital funding may ensure that companies secure sales for the products in the Norwegian market.
Source: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J Q3 Results - Key Takeaways Regarding Zytiga
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Zytiga (abiraterone) sales in the 3rd quarter grew by 75% up 50% in the US and 97% internationally as the benefit of the wider approval for chemonaive CRPC patients started to impact. Sales for the nine months W/W reached $1.2bn +73%.
Pharmaceutical Division Growth
Worldwide pharmaceutical net sales for the third quarter were $7 billion representing an increase of 9.9% versus the same period last year. On an operational basis, sales increased 10.9% with a negative currency impact of 1 point. Sales in the
U.S. increased 7.9% while sales outside the U.S. increased on an
operational basis by 14%
Zytiga
U.S. sales growth of 50% was underpinned byvery strong market growth of nearly 25% and increased market share in the combined metastatic castrate resistant prostate market. Zytiga has captured 33% of that market and is up approximately 2.5 points sequentially y-o-y.
Zytiga sales outside the US nearly doubled on an operational basis versus third quarter of 2012 and on a sequential basis sales were up over 15%. Additional country rollouts and the expansion of the label to chemo nave patients drove the strong results. Zytiga is now approved in more than 80 countries.
Within the US market, it was noted that the split of sales is roughly 55% chemonaive market and 45% in the refractory setting in the quarter. Looking at market growth, refractory grew about 26.5% and nave about 23.5%. Refractory market registered a slight dip from 55% to 55.4% because of new competition, but in the naive segment was 24.6% up from 21%.
Other developments of note in the oncology
Reference was made to the successful completion of the acquisition of Aragon pharmaceuticals, initially announced in June. J&J sees this acquisition as increasing its leadership position in the field of prostate cancer, strengthening its pipeline with a "potentially best in class" compound. It was noted that it has advanced into Phase III development and if approved in the MO treatement setting this would complement Zytiga and broaden the range of patients that
could potentially be treated.
source: www.jnj.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Long-term Gattex Data Supports Label Revision & EU Commercial Launch Is In Sight
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Based on long-term data from the STEPS-2 study released yesterday, at the American College of Gastroenterology, NPS intends to submit a sNDA to the FDA to revise Gattex's (teduglutide) product label. Meanwhile, the company noted that it is preparing to engage in pricing & reimbursement processes in key European countries with the goal of commercially launching Revestive (teduglutide) in Europe 1H14.
STEPS 2 Study Findings
Was a two-year open-label extension study of 88 adult patients with short-bowel syndrome. Investigators noted that long-termuse resulted in additional, clinically meaningful reductions in the volume and days per week of parenteral support requirements. Moreover, 10 of 13 patients who achieved complete independence from parenteral support were those who received 30 months of Gattex in the 6-month pivotal STEPS study and 24 months in STEP2. No new safety concerns have been observed with long-term treatment.
The poster, entitiled " Long-term safety and efficacy of teduglutide for the treatment of intestinal failure associated with short bowel syndrome: Final results of the STEPS2 study, 1 2 -year multicentre, open-label clinical trial" was recogenised as an ACG Presidential Poster Award recipient.
Source: www.nps.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AstraZeneca to Bolster its Portfolio with a New Type of Cancer Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medimmune unit would buy biotech company Spirogen for up to $440M. Spirogen is a clinical stage biotechnology company specialising in novel, sequence-selective, DNA minor groove-binding molecules with potent therapeutic properties.
  • Found in 2000
  • Private
  • 18FTEs
Technology: Spirogen’s Antibody-Drug Conjugate (ADC) technology delivers extremely potent anticancer agents to cancer cells by attaching them to antibodies. Spirogen has developed highly potent warheads based on its proprietory Pyrrolobenzodiazepines (PBDs). These PBD warheads are joined to antibodies by linkers which are stable in the blood stream but release the PBD warhead once it is safely inside the targeted cancer cells.
Pipeline
Spirogen’s lead oncology drug candidate, SG2000, has completed solid tumour Phase I studies in the USA (through the NCI) and Europe (through Cancer Research UK). A Phase II study in cisplatin refractory ovarian cancer is underway in the USA, and a haematological Phase II study is planned in Europe for early 2012.
Partnerships

Q1 2012 - Spirogen enters into licensing agreement with ADC Therapeutics sarl for the provision of PBD warhead and linker technology and associated services for antibody drug conjugate (ADC) development.

Source: Spirogen; ThomsonOne

item.title: France May Be Sanofi's "Biggest Handicap"
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A recent article published by Reuters reports that Sanofi plans 186 net job cuts in French R&D, and wants to regroup scattered R&D sites into hubs. France is "a difficult place to cut costs because of complex labour laws, union opposition and a government eager to protect jobs". The country represents about a third of the company's R&D resources WW.
Sanofi's global workforce is 28,000 people - including around 5,000 in R&D
In addition to the job cuts in R&D, Sanofi plans 453 transfers to other sites.
In the internal memo seen by Reuters, Sanofi said that while it spent more than its peers on research, it took the company on average 20% longer to develop a new drug.
Between 2008 and 2011, Sanofi spent around 105 million euros for each new molecule entering clinical trials, compared to an industry average of about 35 million euros, the memo said.
Source: ThomsonOne

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ESMO Intelligence Part 4 - Ultimate Treatment Sequence for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Given that the therapeutic options have widened for mCRPC patients including taxanes, new hormonal therapies, bone targeted treatments, and vaccine, the next critical question is to determine the optimal sequence. Transition from one treatment to the next is usually based on a combination of clinical, biochemical, and radiologic measures as well as authority guidance. Dr. Loriot disucssed 2 published posters and reviewed currently available evidences and issues for optimal CRPC managment.
Below is what Dr. Loriot presented to illustrate graphically where we are today with the management of CRPC. It is obvious that we have much more options today with the recent approval of abiraterone, enzalutamide, cabazitaxel, radium-223, and sipuleucel-T, as a result, there is more focus on 'when is the right time' and 'what is the right agent of choice'. Mezynski et al. (2012) evaluated activity of docetaxel in 54 mCRPC patients who have been treated previously with abiraterone, and the activity of docetaxel following prior abiraterone appears lower than anticipated and no responses to docetaxel were evident in these patients. Interestingly, Albiges presented cabazitaxel's waterfall plot in 2012 ESMO and demonstrated cabazitaxel's activity in post-abiraterone setting. These findings implicate potential therapeutic benefit to treat patients with cabaxitaxel for patients who have developed resistance to abiraterone therapy.
During poster session on 30th Sept, there were one abstract explored preclinical evidence for cross-resistance between taxanes and abiraterone in mCRPC (Soest et al., Ab#P436) and two abstracts evaluated oucomes with cabazitaxel and abiraterone sequential treatment following docetaxel in mCRPC (Wissing et al., and Sonpavde et al. ab#P412).
Soest et al. : Preclinical evidence for cross-resistance between taxanes and abiraterone in mCRPC
•Given treatment options for mCRPC patients have expanded following availability of new systemic therapies including abiraterone, enzalutamide, and cabazitaxel, the optimal treatment sequence is the hottest topic. Recent clinical studies suggested: 1) impaired efficacy of docetaxel when given after progression on abiraterone in patients with mCRPC; 2) modest efficacy of abiraterone in patients previously treated with enzalutamide and docetaxel; 3) modest efficacy of enzalutamide in patients previously treated with abiraterone and docetaxel
•Preclinical data suggested docetaxel, cabazitaxel and abiraterone all implicate their role in inhibition of AR nuclear transport, thus suggesting a potential mechanism for cross-resistance in mCRPC
•This abstract is to identify cross resistance between docetaxel and cabazitaxel, and hormonal agents abiraterone and enzalutamide, the effects of docetaxel and cabazitaxel on cell viability in PC346Abi101 (abiraterone resistant cell line) and PC346Enza (enzalutamide resistant cell line).
•Docetaxel and cabazitaxel efficacy was significant impaired in both abiraterone and enzalutamide resistant cell line). However, this effect was not observed in mitoxantrone (not targeting microtubules, control) efficacy.
•Interestingly, the extent of efficacy impairment differ for docetaxel and cabazitaxel. The efficacy of docetaxel is impaired more in enzalutamide resistant cell line while cabazitaxel’s efficacy is impaired at a smaller extent. - This may suggest the importance to use different chemotherapeutic agents following progression of either abiraterone or enzalutamide
Wissing et al : A retrospective study on cabazitaxel and abiraterone acetate sequential treatment (CAST) in docetaxel treated metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer patients
  • The aim is to determine the optimal second line therapy strategy for mCRPC patients, for whom both cabzitaxel and abiraterone are appropriate treatment following docetaxel therapy.
  • There is no signiciant difference in OS, however, improvement of biochemical PFS was observed for patients treatment with cabazitaxel → abireaterone
  • Clinical benefit does not depend on duration of prior docetaxel treatment
Similar results were presented by Sonpavde et al. who concluded that cabaxitaxel → abiraterone following docetaxel may be a more optimal sequence. However, these two studies have limitations include small sample size, and data were analysed retrospectively.
In addition to above results, Johann de Bono et al.also published a subanalysis from phase 3 AFFIRM trial to assess benefit from enzalutamide and the impact of duration of prior treatments. Three patient groups were analysed to evaluate the impact on clinical outcome (i.e. OS, rPFS and PSA response based on duration of exposure to prior therapy. These reuslts were highlighted and discussed by Dr. Loriot during poster discussion session and he stated that there were significant improvements in OS, rPFS, and PSA response were observed regardless of duration of prior docetaxel or hormonal therapy. Simlar results were reported from COU-AA-301 trial - there was survivval benefit of abiraterone regardless of duration of docetaxel treatment. However, it is important to also bear in mind that the longer the duration of prior therapy does not equate to longer time for the disease start progressing. The patients can certainly be maintained on previous endocrine therapy while on docetaxel for asymptomatic, slow growing diesease or for patient preference. It would certainly be interesting to analyse the number of patients who have stopped docetaxel due to toxicitiy.
"Should Abiraterone and enzalutamide be given before chemotherapy (given that PREVAIL result is pending)?"
Dr. Loriot commented there are certainly benefits shown in COU-AA-301/302 and AFFIRM trial with less toxicity for both agents. However, the proportion of pateints receiving docetaxel from COU-AA-302 is slightly lower in AA arm than in the control arm (57% vs 63%).
The second abstract that Dr. Loriot discussed was the data published by Small et al. (Abstract #2860) from phase 2 randomised study of sipuleucel-T with either concurrent or sequential abiraterone plus prednisone. Sicne prednisone may impar production of the immunological respsone to sipuleucel-T, this is to evaluate if sipuleucel-T can be administered with concurrent abiraterone+prednisone without deleterious effects on product potency, safety and immunological benefit. The analyses demonstrated there was no evidence suggesting impaired immunological effects of sipuleucel-T in the concurrent treatment arm. These data suggested combination treatment with sipuleucel-T and abiraterone is well tolerated and no major safety concern.
There is certainly strong rationale with no major safety concern to warrent future pivotol combination trials to access clinical outcome benefit. We certainly need to think carefully to select appropriate endpoints that are able to define or measure agent specific clinical benefit.
Despite of few studies investigating cross resistance between taxanes and hormonal treatments (abiraterone and enzalutamide), no strong clinical data up to date could provide guidance for the order in which cemo and AR-dreicted agents are given. Large scale studies are warrented to invesitigate seuqnecing and biomarkers to identify sensitivity and resistance. Appropriate trial design with strong clinical rationale is needed to ensure patients' benefit.
This report was compiled by Jenny Wu (Scientific Intelligence) in collaboration with Jacquie Cantle (Competitive Intelligence).

item.title: Roche to Increase Biologic Manufacturing Capacity Over the Next Five Years
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The 800 million Swiss francs ($877M) investment will support increasing demand for licensed biologic medicines, such as RoACTEMRA (tocilizumab), Kadcyla (trastuzumab emtansine) and Perjeta (pertuzumab), alongside providing a strong foundation for the delivery of 39 investigational biologic medicines in the Roche pipeline. Details of the expansion are provided below.
Biologic manufacturing capacity will be increased at sites in Vacaville and Oceanside in California, U.S with a planned investment of approximately 260 million Swiss francs creating around 250 new jobs.
In Penzberg, Germany, Roche will invest approximately 350 million Swiss francs toward increased manufacturing capacity and equipment refurbishment, creating around 200 positions.
In addition, construction of an antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) production facility will begin in Basel, Switzerland through an investment of over 190 million Swiss francs, which is expected to create 50 jobs. This investment will provide additional capacity and flexibility to support Roche’s first approved ADC, Kadcyla, and a further eight ADCs in clinical development.
Source: Roche

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ESMO Intelligence Part 3 - Novatis's NET Focus & ESMO Guideline Session
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis’s NET presence at ESMO centred on its symposia and an oral presentation of updated RADIANT-2 data. Its symposia focused on combination NET therapy, new molecular targets but also highlighted some relatively recent pasireotide NET data. Soft intelligence leads us to understand that discussions with some KOLs have taken place regarding a new phIII NET study and that the RADIANT-4 interim data is most likely to be presented at ASCO 2014. The ESMO Guideline Session certainly highlighted the interest in SSAs generated by the CLARINET data.
Symposia Highlights – "The GI Tumour Challenge"
The symposia provided an overview of the latest scientific data for advanced NET, GIST and HCC, highlighting the need in each area to develop and more personalised approach to patient treatment.
Christos Toumpanakis (Royal Free London) presented the NET section of the symposia. He highlighted the range of different antiproliferative treatments available and the expanding knowledge of NET tumour biology resulting in a number of new agents being trialed. He emphasised the need for further rational combination therapy to be evaluated to try to improve treatment outcomes.
Turning his attention to biomarkers, he focused on the established predictive nature of Chromagainin and NSE and the range of novel biomarkers that can potentially be explored.
Focus then turned to the antiproliferative effect of SSAs in GEP-NET, the long-term OS results of the PROMID study and then the new NET data on the phIII pasireotide study first presented in poster only form at ASCO 2013.
To recap, the primary endpoint of this phIII study was symptomatic control. A negative futility analysis resulted in the study being terminated early in February 2012 with no difference being demonstrated in symptom control. Data for one of the secondary endpoints however, is more positive with the PFS data demonstrating a 5 month improvement in the pasireotide group vs. octreotide (11.8 vs. 6.8 HR 0.46 p=0.045),
Toumpanakis concluded by stating that potentially pasireotide could be another promising agent in NET.
Interestingly, we understand some discussions with investigators took place at ESMO with regard to the future of pasireotide in NET and a possible new phIII study design. The question remains as to whether if this occurs it would be conducted with the current formulation or now that a deal with Camurus has been confirmed, a new fluid crystal formulation.
Data Highlighted on Novartis’s Booth
The medical affairs section of the Novartis Booth was highlighting a number of new agents that are being evaluated for NET including the PI3 K inhibitor BEZ235 and the fibroblast growth factor inhibitor dovitinib.
Turning to the promotional side of the booth, key messaging for Sandostatin LAR is as shown below with the focus on the PROMID data and the new device.
Interestingly, two people manning the booth, when questioned about the RADIANT-4 study noted that accrual was completed in August 2013 and that there is an expectation that interim data will be presented at ASCO next year. Whether Novartis will be in a position to file based on this interim data remains to be seen but in all recent investor presentations it has highlighted 2015 as the year that it will file for approval in GEP-NETS (non-functioning mid-gut and pulmonary) based on the RADIANT-4 data.
ESMO Guideline Session
This is a session repeated every year but it was of particular interest this year to see how clinicians reacted in the context of the newly released CLARINET data.
The session was introduced with some general comments on the guidelines themselves, noting that the main updates are every 2-5 years. The number of new guidelines produced per year is declining but the usage of the guidelines is substantially increasing having more than doubled since 2009. There are now 6 pocket guidelines available on mobiles including one on NET. ESMO is currently working on a number of guidelines for patients covering 16 different topics including bladder and prostate.
The NET session that followed examined a patient case history and asked people to vote on their next choice of therapy at the point of progression. The patient was diagnosed with a metastatic G2 pNET Ki67 8%. Interestingly, when the audience was asked which treatment they would recommend time and time again their first choice was a SSA, although this was not how the patient was treated. As you will note he was treated according to the ESMO guidelines and progressively treated with different MTTs
Interesting to note the continued interest in prescribing SSAs and that a higher % of the audience recommended liver directed therapy over PRRT (20% vs 15%).
.
In the discussion that followed K Oberg stated “I am happy to see everybody voting time and time again for SSAs after the CLARINET data yesterday”.
He proceeded to highlight the range of treatment options that could be considered including chemotherapy and in particular presented two slides one showing the antiproliferative effects of SSAs prior to the CLARINET data and the other recent data from chemotherapy trials. He highlighted the temozolamide phII 2010 data where a PR was observed in 70% of patient and PGS was 18 months but emphasised the need for a controlled trial to validate these findings.
He questioned why targeted agents were used to treat the patient when at that time they were still being trialed and asked what was the reason for not giving chemotherapy or for that matter PRRT. The problem he acknowledged is that we have no randomised trials comparing chemotherapy vs. targeted agents. He concluded that chemotherapy is still a valid alternative for this type of patient.
Key Posters
The following key posters were presented with a handful presented in an oral review session. All are attached for your reference. The number of GSK supported pazopanib posters was notable.
  1. Updated OS data from the RADIANT-2 study which has demonstrated no difference in OS a study that was compromised by the crossover of patients from the placebo –OCT LAR arm to the everolimus arm.
  2. A study from British Columbia evaluating Ytrium 90 radioembolisation for hepatic metastases which included 20 ~NET patients amongst the 41 patients evaluated in total, which concludes that the NET patients appeared to derive the most benefit from the procedure.
  3. Phase II first line study of combination everolimus and octreotide LAR in 50 patients with well differentiated NETS of gastroenteropancreatic and lung origin.conducted by the ITMO group. The ORR data of 20% was considered a promising finding and data that complements that obtained in RADIANT-2
  4. Real world everolimus data demonstrating that efficacy is found to be similar to that reported in ph3 trials with equal results in both pNETs and non-PNETs. However, a 2-fold increase in severe toxicity incidence is observed in patients who have previously benn treated with PRRT or chemotherapy raising the question of influence of previous teratments on the severity of adverse events that can be expected during everolimus treatment.
  5. PhII Single-arm trial of pazopanib (GSK) in patients with progressive GEP-NETs. 44 patients who had failed chemotherapy, SSAs or MTTs received pazopanib 800mg q.d. Patients showed remarkable activity regardless of previous MTT treatment raising the hypothesis of non-cross resistance between MTTs in this population and possibly justifying the use of sequential targeted therapies. A phIII study of pazopanib in progressive GEPNETs is now planned.
  6. QOL Assessments from an expanded access part of the RADIANT-3 study concluding that throughout the treatment period as reported by patients and assessed by QLQ-C30 and QLQ-GINET21, everolimus maintained QOL in patients with pNET.
  7. Results of long-term radiological follow-up of patients in the PROMID trial. Data shows that patients with well differentiated mid-gut tumours low hepatic tumour load (HL) is predictive for better response to early octreotide LAR therapy. High HL is associated with a shorter overall survival.
  8. Real word efficacy data regarding sunitinib and everolimus from UKINETS demonstating lower but approaching published efficacy data in heavily pre-treated patients.
  9. A single-centre study demonstrating similar effiacy with both octreotide LAR and lanreotide LAR in terms of PFS in both pNET and GI-NET.
  10. Pazopanib treatment is associated with a decrease in plasma sVEGFR2. A stonger decrease is associated with improved PFS especially in patients without prior anti-angiogenic therapy.

item.title: Canadian Real Life Evaluation of Lupron® for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The objective of the CRONOS II is to assess the effect of diet and exercise in patients managed with Lupron®. PE will evaluate the changes in patient QoL using the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form.
Start date: September 2013 (currently recruiting participants)
Completion date: November 2020
About the Questionnaire
The SF-36 Health is a 36-item general health self-administered questionnaire consisting of 8 scales measuring Physical Function, Physical Role limitations, Vitality, General Health, Pain, Social Function, Emotional Role limitations, and Mental Health.
Approx. 860
Will be enrolled from the offices of University or community uro/radio-onco across Canada treating patients with prostate cancer.
  • AbbVie
  • CMX Research Inc
  • JSS Medical Research Inc

Reference in clinicaltrials.gov NCT01960881

item.title: Cosmo's Methylene Blue MMX® to Enter Registration Trials for Colon Cancer Diagnosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Poster presentation on phase II at EUGW in Berlin.
- to deliver Methylene Blue along the length of the entire colon via the MMX® technology thus enabling endoscopists to better detect pre-cancerous and cancerous lesions and polyps throughout the entire colon.
- allows the delivery of active pharmaceutical ingredients into the lumen of the colon through tablets in a delayed and controlled extent with the effect that the active pharmaceutical ingredients can be applied to the full length of the colon.
The tablets manufactured according to the MMX® technology are coated with pH-resistant acrylic copolymers which delay the release until the tablet reaches the indicated intestinal location where the programmed dissolution begins. That allows for protection of the active substances from adverse pH conditions and enzymatic presence in the upper digestive tracts. The controlled release over the length of the colon not only simplifies the application for the patients but allows for the topical application of the active pharmaceutical ingredients to the whole bowel surface that is affected by inflammations.
This technology may also be used for other diseases affecting the colon and can be used as a platform for applications outside the colon where a controlled release is of importance.
Source: Cosmo

item.title: re: Bayer Highlights 5 New NMEs and Life-Cycle Intention Plans for Radium-223 In CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Bayer Highlights 5 New NMEs and Life-Cycle Intention Plans for Radium-223 In CRPC 
Comment: Bayer hosted an investor meeting in London today and confirmed its intention to accelerate the clinical develompent of five new promisining NMEs including, an oral progesterone receptor modulator for patients with symptomatic uterine fibroids. Additionally, it highlighted its intentions to develop Radium 223 Xofigo for earlier stages of the CRPC treatment paradigm in combination with abiraterone.  ...
Thanks to Stefan Pfeifer (Uro BU Director in Germany) we have learnt that Bayer has established a Xofigo sales force of 5 reps for the German market.
One source reported that the targets are nuclear medicine centers plus referring retail urologists but this needs to be confirmed by a 2nd source.

Comment: Bayer hosted an investor meeting in London today and confirmed its intention to accelerate the clinical develompent of five new promisining NMEs including, an oral progesterone receptor modulator for patients with symptomatic uterine fibroids. Additionally, it highlighted its intentions to develop Radium 223 Xofigo for earlier stages of the CRPC treatment paradigm in combination with abiraterone.  ...
Thanks to Emannuelle Nuris France Uro-Oncology BU Head we have learnt that Bayer is re-organising its one oncology sales force which was promoting Nexavar towards Gastro-enterologists & GI onco & Uro-onco prescribers into 2 sales forces. One will focus on Uro-Onco prescribers and in terms of product on Nexavar in renal cancer & Alpharadin in CRPC, whilst the 2nd one will focus on Gastroenterologists and GI Onco and will promote Nexavar in GI indications + a new product (t.b.d.).
Effective as of now.

item.title: Mallinckrodt Consolidates Leadership in Nuclear Imaging
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has licensed a third US patent for Octreoscan™ imaging agent. The patent, U.S. 6,123,916, effective through September 26, 2017, covers the use of Octreoscan™ imaging agent to detect Merkel cell carcinoma (a type of neuroendocrine tumor, which is a rare, aggressive form of skin cancer).
Octreoscan imaging agent is a diagnostic radiopharmaceutical, used to detect certain neuroendocrine tumors.
U.S. patents 5,753,627 and 5,776,894 granted in 1998.
Business
- API, generics, and branded pharmaceuticals business, and then we - global imaging (contrast media and devices, as well as a imaging business).
  • Staff: approx. 5,500 employees worldwide
  • Geo coverage: sales in roughly 90 countries.
  • 2012 revenue: $2.1 billion.
Source: Mallinckrodt

item.title: Lexicon's Telotristat Etiprate Did Not Work in UC Ph2
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Although LX1032 (Telotristat etiprate) did lower 5-HIAA and was safe and well-tolerated, reducing 5-HIAA did not have enough of an impact on UC to move forward with this indication. Lexicon plans to maintain the focus of its resources on the ongoing Ph 3 program in carcinoid syndrome as the primary indication for the drug.
Design: multicenter study.
Recruitment: 59 patients with mild-moderate ulcerative colitis.
Intervention: 500 mg dose of investigational drug telotristat etiprate taken orally once daily, or a 500 mg dose of telotristat etiprate three times daily.
Duration: Treatment was given for 8 weeks.
Next steps > In the context of a pilot study, additional analyses will be conducted to best understand the clinical significance of the results, which are planned for presentation at a scientific congress in 2014.
Wedbush estimate LX1032 for carcinoid syndrome may be launched in 2015, LX1033 for IBS-d in 2016 and LX4211 for diabetes in 2017.
Source: http://www.lexgen.com/news/press-releases/2299-lexicon-completes-pilot-study-of-telotristat-etiprate-in-ulcerative-colitis.html

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: May Botox(R) Be an Alternative to Fight Fat ?
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Within the frame of an EU project called 'Full4Health Program', researchers from the Norwegian U. of Science and Technology have had promising experimental results in rats, and hope to start human clinical studies soon. Prior to publishing this article, I got written confirmation that the toxin drug tested is Botox (the brand). Although Allergan is looking to divest its 'obesity intervention unit', we may bear in mind that the company is still committed to fight 'obesity', and be interested in a new approach of the disease with Botox should this project succeed.
Findings show that injection into the vagus nerve in the stomach can lead to weight loss (animals ate less and lost 20-30% of their body weight over 5 weeks).
Paralyzing the nerve paralyzes muscles in the stomach, which appears to slow the passage of food through the stomach.
Use of Botox(R) in this condition can be developed into an alternative to gastric bypass surgery.
The company is actively pursuing the development of next-generation products and technologies capable of providing high-quality, healthier, and less traumatic long-term weight-loss treatment solutions (Allergan's website).
In the US alone, obesity affects >60 million individuals (NIH, 2005; Merrill Lynch, May 2006; Monitor Group), and is considered the second leading cause of preventable death (American Obesity Association. AOA Fact Sheets).
Worldwide, approx. 1.6 billion adults are overweight, and it is estimated that obesity affects at least 400 million adults (World Health Organization, 2005).
A €9 million EU Framework 7 project which brings together 19 multidisciplinary academic and industry collaborators from across Europe.
The project will investigate mechanisms of hunger, satiety and feeding behaviour, and how these change across the life course, effects of dietary components and food structure on these processes, and their possible exploitation in addressing obesity, chronic disease and under-nutrition (http://www.full4health.eu/project/).
Source: Science Daily; Allergan; ThomsonOne

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ESMO Intelligence Part 2 - Treatment Approach in CRPC with Bone Metastases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ESMO 2013 continues with tremendous focus on prostate cancer management. Unlike the decade, the landscape of prostate cancer has changed dramatically with the new generation of AR targeting agents that have widen treatment options for patients. However, Bone mets remain the major cause of morbidities and mortalities in prostate cancer. Bone mets in prostate cancer have distinctive pattern of complications including pain, fracture, and spinal cord compression. Bayer and Amgen held a industry sponsored satellite symposium to discuss the role of bone targeted treatments for mCRPC patients with bone metastases.
Historically strontium-89 and samarium-153 are the two β-emitters approved for pain palliation. Due the nature of β-emitting radiation, the risk of increase bone marrow exposure may result in bone marrow associated toxicities. There are several studies evaluating the role of zoledronic acid in non-metastatic CRPC , however, ZEUS trial did not meet its primary endpoint where zoledronic acid vs placebo was not able to demonstrate 1) superiority to delay development of bone metastases (13.7% vs 13%, p=0.717); 2) OS benefit (p=0.717).
Amgen then conducted a Phase III bone metastases prevention trial in patients with high risk of CRPC. Denosumab demonstrated significant prolonged bone metastasis free survival (BMFS) vs placebo by 4.3 months with hazard ratio of 0.85 (95% CI, 0.73-0.98; p=0.028). A subgroup analysis demonstrated denosumab markedly prolonged BMFS by greater than 7 months in patients with PSA doubling time less than 6 months. Denosumab significantly prolonged BMFS vs placebo in men with high risk non metastatic CRPC and this validates a potential therapeutic role in non metastatic CRPC patients. In 2010, Amgen's denosumab was approved based on its superiority for delay of time to first skeletal related event (SRE) compared to zoledronic acid despite of similar OS. This results implicate the potential role of bone targeted agents in delaying disease progression, unfotunately it has not translated into overall survival!
A new bone targeted agent, Radium 223, has been approved by FDA based on increased OS as well as improvement of first symptomatic SRE . In the Bayer sponsored satellite symposium, Professor Fred Saad pointed out that radium 223 is the first bone targeted therapy has demonstrated survival benefit as well as pain palliation. Radium 223 is a water soluble radium salt that emits four alpha particles during decay of each isotope. Radium 223 is FDA approved for the treatment of symptomatic CRPC and bone metastases with no evidence of visceral disease. Dr. Stephane Oudard presented Phase 3 ALSYMPCA demonstrated OS benefit in both pre- and post- docetaxel setting. This indicates radium 223 may have a role in pre-chemo setting.
Dr. Oliver Sartor also discussed why SRE is an important end point as management of SREs is associated with substantial health resource utilisation. The importance of early identification of bone mets could be important in delaying patient morbidity and mortality. There are evidences demonstrating patients who had more than 4.6 positive area on bone scan (PABI) associate with lower probabllity of survival. Radium 223 can be beneficial in this setting.
Four poster abstracts (Ab# 2876, 2877, 2878, and 2883) discussed Phase 3 ALSYMPCA findings in terms of time to first symptomatic skeletal event (SSE), haematologic safety, impact on quality of life (QoL) .
  • In all age groups, radium 223 prolonged OS, time to first SSE, time to an increase in total ALP, time to an increase in PSA
  • Radium 223 prolongs time to first SSE regardless of baseline stratification factors (current bisphosphonate use, prior docetaxel use, and baseline ALP levels). Although results suggested a greater effect in the subgroup who received bisphosphonate, this interpretation needs to be taken with caution as this was a non-randomised comparison.
  • Haematologic AEs and bone marrow failure are frequent complications of metastatic CRPC disease progression and treatment - radium 223 treatment arm had a low incidence of haematologic AEs and no major difference in grade 3 or 4 haaematologic toxicity compared to placebo groups.
  • Radium 223 better preserved QoL in terms of physical, emotional and functional subscales and specifically pain related QoL (i.e decreased pain)
The question remains when to use radium 223 despite of its promising safety and efficacy data - below are the quoations from expert:
"The more symptomatic they are the more I will be thinking of radium"
'It’s kind of depending on burden of bone and symptoms"
Dr Smith stated "This is clearly, I believe, an important therapeutic option for patients with advanced disease" and he presented a case, who received combination therapy with abiraterone + radium 223, demonstrated PSA nadir <2 ng/ml within 8 weeks and a remarkable resolution of bone disease at month 8.
Dr Sartor also presented a case: 67-year-old mCRPC patients with bone metastases and seeking NON-CHEMOTHERAPY treatment options to maintain his active lifesstyle. The patient received abiraterone + prednisone and then radium 223 inhections every 4 weeks were added to the secondary hormonal regime. Two months after injections, the patient experienced pain relief and test result demonstrated reduction of ~70% in PSA nad 60% in alkaline phosphatase. The patient continues to have a actrive life style. For many years, docetaxel was the only agent shown to prolong survival in mCRPC, given more options are available now, patients may now have an important voice in treatment decision process.
Sartor pointed out " we now have many options in US and the post-docetaxel space is losing meaning except to insureres and regulators. The post-abiraterone space is much more important today, however, we know little about it." Radium 223 may have a role in this setting, but the ALYSYMPCA Phase III trial has a number of critical unanswered question: 1) what is the MOA to improve clinical outcome? 2) Pain was not systematically evaluated in the trial and requires further investigation 3) efficacy and safety of combination therapy. However, we remain sceptical in terms of EMA approval of radium 223 in pre-chemo setting based on ALSYMPCA trial as the comparison arm only received placebo. Further trials are warranted to compare efficacy in pre-chemo setting.

item.title: Versartis Raises $20M Series D Venture Financing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This new financing round brings the company's total venture capital raised in 2013 to $45M. Management reported the new capital will support the preparation for an international Ph3 trial of LA hGH in Ped. patients planned to start in 2014.
NCT01718041 - The company’s VERTICAL study of VRS-317 in pre-pubertal children with GHD is currently being conducted in approx 30 sites in the US and was initiated following the successful results of a Ph1 study in adults with GHD.
The VERTICAL study is designed in two stages:

- the Phase 1b utilized a single ascending-dose design to evaluate the safety and tolerability of six dosing levels of a subcutaneous (SC) dose of VRS-317.

- the Phase 2a was initiated last month and will further study these patients to determine the efficacy of VRS-317 as defined by an increase in height velocity over 3 and 6 months of treatment.

See Endocrinology7238: Versartis Closed $25M Series C Financing.
Source: Versartis

item.title: ADT +/- Local RT +/- Abiraterone in Metastatic Hormone-naïve Prostate Cancer (PEACE1)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3, sponsored by UNICANCER, will compare the clinical benefit of ADT with or without local radiotherapy with or without abiraterone acetate and prednisone in patient with metastatic hormone-naïve prostate cancer. The randomisation will result in the allocation of arm A (ADT), arm B (ADT + Abiraterone), arm C (ADT + radiotherapy) or arm D (ADT + Abiraterone + radiotherapy) in a 1:1:1:1 ratio. PE will assess survival.

item.title: Octreolin Intelligence From Two Recent Surveys
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Over the course of the last six-months, two sources of intelligence on Octreolin have identified a number of points regarding the efficacy, safety and positioning of the drug and Roche's involvement with the programme. The first set of data came from a primary intelligence survey conducted by the CI Dept. in Europe involving 8 KOLs & undertaken between April and June 2013, and the second is feedback from a recent US ad-board held on the 16th September. Thanks to Dan Commerford (Senior Director US Marketing) for sharing this with us.
A summary of some of the key conclusions from both studies is shown below but we would welcome any further information you have on the points raised:
From a regulatory standpoint, primary intelligence highlighted Roche's ambition to file a.s.a.p for the treatment of acromegaly and if possible in the 1H2014. However, with datalock as highighted below not occuring until the end of the quarter these timelines could be stretched. Sources from Genentech interviewed at ENDO stated that a decision on FDA filing will be taken at the time of data release as to whether or not a separate US based trial will be required/undertaken.
Chiasma itself has for some time been pointing to a filing in both the US & EU in Q114.
There is no evidence at the current time of a planned NET study and as far as we understand none of the clinicians involved with octreolin have been approached regarding such a study. Some specialists have questioned the feasibility of adminstering an oral agent to patients with functional tumours, albeit for non-functioning tumours this could be less of an issue.
US Ad Board Key Findings

item.dc:creator: spoon

First FFA2 Inhibitor to be Evaluated Clinically 
Comment: Galapagos reported that the positive outcome of the phase 1 study with GLPG0974 supports progression to a POC trial next month for ulcerative colitis (UC).  ...
The drug has entered into the first Ph2 trial for testing safety and efficacy, with top-line results expected Q1:14.
Trial Details
  • Design: Four-week study with approx. 45 patients with mild to moderate UC
  • Objective: to assess efficacy, effects on selected biomarkers, afety and tolerability and PK.
  • Regimen: patients will receive either 200 mg of the drug twice-daily or placebo for a period of 4 weeks.
  • Location: Belgium; Latvia; Czech Rep. and Slovakia.
Source: Galapagos

item.title: Bayer Highlights 5 New NMEs and Life-Cycle Intention Plans for Radium-223 In CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bayer hosted an investor meeting in London today and confirmed its intention to accelerate the clinical develompent of five new promisining NMEs including, an oral progesterone receptor modulator for patients with symptomatic uterine fibroids. Additionally, it highlighted its intentions to develop Radium 223 Xofigo for earlier stages of the CRPC treatment paradigm in combination with abiraterone.
Potential New NMEs
Amongst the 5 NMEs highlighted were 3 cardiovascular agents, one oncology compound and a new treatment for uterine fibroids
BAY 1002670
Is a novel oral progesterone receptor modulator that holds the promises of long-term treatment of patients with symptomatic uterine fibroids. Based on promising early clinical data the initiation of a Phase III study is planned for mid-2014.
Meanwhile, in oncology, Copanlisib (BAY 80-6946), a novel, oral phosphatidylinositol-3 kinases (PI3K) inhibitor, has been selected for accelerated development in patients with follicular lymphoma. A Phase II study in patients with Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is currently ongoing.
Xofigo - Radium 223
Alongside its discussion of potential NMEs, Bayer was also keen to emphasise the life-cycle opportunities for some of its newer products including the CRPC agent Xofigo which is now commercially available in both the US and Europe. The most interesting aspect of its development programme is its decision to move into earlier treatment settings within the CPRC treatment pardigm with plans to conduct a combination study with abiraterone (see deisgn below).

Comments
Thanks to Emannuelle Nuris France Uro-Oncology BU Head we have learnt that Bayer is re-organising its one oncology sales force which was promoting Nexavar towards Gastro-enterologists & GI onco & Uro-onco prescribers into 2 sales forces. One will focus on Uro-Onco prescribers and in terms of product on Nexavar in renal cancer & Alpharadin in CRPC, whilst the 2nd one will focus on Gastroenterologists and GI Onco and will promote Nexavar in GI indications + a new product (t.b.d.).
Effective as of now.
Thanks to Stefan Pfeifer (Uro BU Director in Germany) we have learnt that Bayer has established a Xofigo sales force of 5 reps for the German market.
One source reported that the targets are nuclear medicine centers plus referring retail urologists but this needs to be confirmed by a 2nd source.

item.title: Allergan/MedyTox Licensing Agreement - Further Assumptions
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Further to the announcement of a potential licensing agreement on September 26th, a number of Asian investment houses have clearly had further discussions with Medytox and highlighted some assumptions about the future development plan for MT101019 and are forecasting a potential market share of 20%.
Nomura (see below) has highlighted the development schedule of the next generation Meditoxin MT10109 (the freeze-dried, HSA free (utilises plant protein instead), room temperature product) quoting the company as the source of development timelines.
The chart notes that phIII in Korea is complete. Although there is no reference to any phIII study in any of the clinical trial databases, including the Korean database CRIS, we believe the lead indication studied was glabellar lines. Intelligence gained earlier in the year (see Neurology6888: Nomura Highlights Medy-Tox As One Of Its Top Buys Due To Export Growth & Emerging Potential Of Next Generation Toxin) did suggest that Medytox had filed for approval in March 2013. Seemingly, the contract with Allergan is contingent on this approval in Korea. The timelines as you will note suggest a global phIII trial will start in the fourth quarter and complete within 1 year, followed by regulatory submissions in the US thereafter and launch in 2H16.
Two phII studies with MT10109, that are highlighted in the public domain have been undertaken in Australia, We are aware that Medytox is hoping to use these as part of any global submission, one has been conducted in glabellar lines and the other in cervical dsytonia. The former completed in August 2012 and the latter was scheduled to complete last month.
Liquid Toxin Status
Meanwhile, the Korean clinical trial database CRIS is currently listing a phI trial with another Medy-Tox product MT101017. The trial is a 25 patient phI study which started recruitement in September last year. Our current assumption (to be validated) is that this is a trial with the new next generation liquid toxin, something that was also referred to in the Allergan/Medy-Tox press release as being part of the agreement.
This is a randomised, double-blind, intra-individual controlled, dose escalation study to assess the safety, tolerability and preliminary effectiveness of a single dose of MT10107 in comparison to Botox®50U (BOTOX® is a registered trademark owned by Allergan). This is the first-in-human study for MT10107, and will be performed in healthy volunteers.
Given both Nomura and Woori appear to be both talking about a peak market share in the US & EU of 20%, we suspect some guidance has been given by Medy-Tox to this effect.
We hope that we will have more concrete data to back up some of these assumptions before the end of the year.
Sources.
CRIS http://cris.nih.go.kr/cris/en/search/search_result_st01.jsp?seq=2729
Nomura report September 27th
Woori report September 27th
Shinhan Investment Corp report September 27th

item.title: J&J's SIMPONI® (golimumab) Approved in the EU
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: European Commission has approved SIMPONI® (golimumab) for the treatment of moderately to severely active UC in adult patients who have had an inadequate response to conventional therapy including corticosteroids and 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) or azathioprine (AZA), or who are intolerant to or have medical contraindications for such therapies. The drug is the first and only subcutaneous anti–tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha treatment administered as an every-4-week maintenance therapy for UCF.
Prior to Simponi's approval, the only other TNF blocking options were J&J's Remicade (infliximab), and AbbVie's Humira (adalimumab).
GlobalData’s primary research has uncovered concerns among KOLs who believe that TNF blocker usage carries a significant financial burden of aftercare, and adverse-event management expenses.
The aftercare and adverse-event expenses associated with biologics treatment are estimated at around $28,000 annually per TNF blocker patient in the US as infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, hepatitis virus flares, and opportunistic lung infections can raid UC patients treated with TNF blockers.
Colectomy still comprises a significant part of UC management because: one, not all severe patients will respond to the anti-TNF treatments, and two, the total response to these therapies has seen a gradual decline in the last decade.
Hospira’s Inflectra, a biosimilar to J&J Remicade (infliximab) was approved by the European Commission for marketing in the EU for multiple autoimmune diseases including rheumatoid arthritis (RA), Crohn’s disease (CD), ulcerative colitis (UC), ankylosing spondylitis (AS), and psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
Although approved for marketed use in the EU, Inflectra’s launch will be pending based on potential intellectual property protections.
Source: Company PR, GlobalData

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sirtex - Sir-Sphere Application in NET Therapy & Reimbursement Coverage By NHS England for mCRC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At the upcoming EANM meeting in Lyon, a significant amount of data will be presented in oral sessions on the usage of PRRT to treat neuroendocrine tumours. Sirtex will also be present, featuring its SIR-Spheres during a lunch time symposium, talking about future directions with SIRT amongst them its use for the treatment of liver metastases in NET. The speaker Dr Hojjat Ahmadzadehfar has published a number of papers on the use of PRRT for NET therapy. Interestingly SIRT has recently become the first treatment under the new UK CtE initiative to be funded for the treatment of mCRC and ICC.
For those interested in a full listing of PRRT events that will take place in Lyon please contact Jacquie Cantle
Sirtex's Presence At ESMO
Interestingly, Sirtex were recently present at ESMO distributing a supplement on its booth from the 4th European symposium on Liver-Directed Cancer Therapy using Sir-Spheres included in which was a chapter on SIRT for neuroendocrine tumours. An overview of NET liver mets by P Ruszniewski (France) and a paper on SIRT therapy by L Bester (Syndey Australia) were included. Dr Bester concludes that "SIRT with 90Y microspheres is a promising treatment option for unresectable NETLM and that patients with low hepatic tumour burden, well differentiated tumour and no extrahepatic disease are the best candidates for SIRT."
It should be pointed out that at this juncture, SIRT is not a licensed therapy for the treatment of neuroendocrine tumours but there appears to be a growing interest in its application (see Endocrinology7198: The Consensus Conference On NET-Liver-Metastases - London Dec 13th 2012). Emory University is currently conducting a study evaluating pasireotide everolimus and SIRT in a phI/II study that is examining the safety of the combination. The study is scheduled to complete by the end of this year.
New Reimbursement Development For Sirtex
Regarding the recent development for Sirtex in the UK, Sir-Spheres represent the first treatement under the new Commissioning through Evaluation (CtE) initiative to be funded within defined parameters in a small number of participating centres and within an explicit evaluation programm for a period of 1-2 years. The CtE allows treatments or services that are not routinely funded by the NHS.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Highlights of Allergan's Activities at WCN 2013 (Sept. 21-26 Vienna, Austria)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan's symposium focused on the effect of BOTOX(R) on sensory and motor pathways, and the evidence for its role across cervical dystonia (CD), chronic migraine (CM), and neurogenic detrusor overactivity (NDO). The possible direct or indirect benefit of BoNT-A on the non-motor symptoms of CD was discussed, among other key topics highlighted below. The presented posters covered baseline data from CD-PROBE, as well as results of three studies and safety results from a pooled analysis in lower limb spasticity.
Professor O. Dolly (Mayo Clinic College of Medicine, Scottsdale, Arizona) concluded a very scientific session outlining that BoNT-A is a versatile inhibitor of the exocytosis of cell mediators from motor, autonomic and sensory neurons that displays specificity, potency, prolonged clinical benefit, and a well proven safety profile.
For Doctor Marion Simonetta-Moreau (Toulouse U. Hospital, Toulouse, France) cervical dystonia is more than a motor condition. Patients with CD frequently meet criteria for anxiety disorders, especially social phobia (71%) and major depressive disorder (present in about 15-55% of patients).
She highlighted that pain is present in 67-75% of CD patients and can be the most disabling feature of the disease.
Non-motor symptoms contribute significantly to the functional disability induced by CD, and have negative impact on health-related QoL, and could represent therapeutic targets to relieve dystonia.
She concluded that :
- there is a need for a scale that considers both motor AND non-motor symptoms in CD,
- multidisciplinary burden care is imperative (neurologists, physiotherapists, psychiatrics and pain specialists),
- BoNT injections are helpful to alleviate sensorimotor symptoms but often not enough.
During a 45-minute "Meet the Expert" session hosted on Allergan exhibition booth, she was questionned on dysphagia, pain in CD, and doses.
She answered that :
- incidence of dysphagia after injection depends on 1-/dose injected 2-/the product and 3-/the volume of the muscles.
- pain in CD is not completely explained by the contractions and the musculoskeletal forces. There is a strong evidence that BoNT also has effect on other neuromediators involved in pain.
- doses depend on the volume of the muscles. For example, women at first injection not up to 40 U, and for 2nd injection up to 60U.
Professor Clare Fowler (UK) presented the results of two Ph3 trials (DIGNITY), which demonstrate that the targeted sensorimotor action of BOTIX(R) significantly reduced the number of UI episodes experienced by patients with either MS or SCI allowing 37% of patients to achieve complete continence at wk6 vs only 9% with placebo (Kennelly M, et al. J Urol 2013;81:491-7).
She concluded that:
Professor David Dodick (USA) started his presentation by highlighting the global prevalence of chronic migraine (CM), that affects 1-3% of the population WW. The condition is associated with sensitisation of central sensory neural pathways and functional/structural brain changes.
CM is responsive to BoNT-A (BOTOX) due to its effect on the sensory afferent pathways.
Cervical Dystonia Patient Registry for Observation of OnabotulinumtoxinA Efficacy (CD PROBE): Pain at Baseline
CD is the most common focal movement disorder, and pain is one of its most common and disabling features (Albanese A, et al. Mov Disord. 2013;28:863-873).
OnabotulinumtoxinA Efficacy in Lower Limb Spasticity: Results of Three Studies (full poster attached )
  • 300U significantly decreases ankle flexor tone in adults with post strole lower lib spasticity.
  • Treated patients experienced greater improvements per the investigator's overall assessment.
Neurorehabilitation OnabotulinumtoxinA in lower limb spasticity: Safety results from a pooled analysis
  • OnabotulinumtoxinA treatment in LLS was well tolerated. The majority of AEswere considered not related to onabotulinumtoxinA, and treatment-related AEs were consistent with the known mechanism of action of onabotulinumtoxinA.

item.title: Tekmira Presents PhI NET Data At NANETS Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Late last week, Tekmira presented data from a phI study with its polo-like kinase inhibitor TKM-PLK-1 at NANETS. The study was undertaken in 36 advanced cancer patients including two patients with GI-NET. The reduction in Chromagainin levels seen with the drug and the patient's response to treatment has supported the initiation of a phI/II study in NET & ACC patients, a trial that is now ongoing and expected to read-out in mid 2014.
PhI Study Results
40%(6 out of 15) of patients in the phI study evaluable for response, treated at a dose equal to or greater than 0.6 mg/kg, showed clinical benefit.
Of the 36 patients enrolled, three out of the four ACC patients (75%) treated with TKM-PLK1 achieved stable disease, including one patient who saw a 19.3% reduction in tumor size and is still on study receiving TKM-PLK1.
Of the two GI-NET patients enrolled, both experienced clinical benefit: one patient had a partial response based on RECIST criteria, and the other GI-NET patient achieved stable disease and showed a greater than 50% reduction in Chromogranin-A (CgA) levels, a key biomarker used to predict clinical outcome and tumor response.
Next Steps
The company has stated that it is are encouraged that a GI-NET patient who achieved stable disease showed a greater than 50% decline in CgA levels and that it intends to CgA data in its ongoing TKM-PLK1 Phase I/II clinical trial.
It expects to have results from this completed trial by mid-2014 and if the data is postiive commence a pivotal trial in GI-NET in 2014.
The company is hosting an R&D investor presentation tomorrow at 4pm EST to review this data and company pipeline information in more detail.

Comments
Last Thursday Tekmira raised $30 million through the sale of 3.8 million shares at $8 in a follow-on underwritten by Stifel and Maxim Group. Tekmira proposed the offering late Wednesday, when its share price on NASDAQ was $8.82. Tekmira's lead internal candidate is TKM-PLK1, which is in Phase I/II testing to treat advanced gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumors and adrenocortical carcinoma, with data expected in mid-2014. TKM-PLK1 comprises short interfering RNA (siRNA) targeting polo-like kinase 1 formulated with the company's lipid nanoparticle (LNP) technology.
